Get e-AlertsAbstractThe partitioning and transport of proteins in anionic, polyacrylamide-based gels were characterized by a direct visualization method using cytochrome c as the probe molecule. Homogeneous gels stabilized against mechanical and osmotic forces were made by synthesizing them inside fused-silica capillaries with a square cross section. Mixtures of 2-acrylamido-2-methylpropane sulfonic acid and acrylamide as the starting co-monomers and N,N‘-methylene bisacrylamide as a cross-linker were used in preparing these gels. After polymerization and equilibration of the samples in a buffer, the diffusional transport of cytochrome c was studied via the microscopic determination of the evolution of concentration profiles in the gel upon exposure to a protein solution. Calibrated digitized profiles were used to determine the protein diffusivity in the gel and the effects of boundary-layer mass-transfer resistance on transient adsorption and desorption. The effects of protein and salt concentrations in solution and the effects of the gel composition were determined. The ranges of experimental conditions covered gels with cross-link densities between 2.5 and 10%, total polymer concentrations between 0.05 and 0.42 g/cm3, and charge densities between 97 and 970 μequiv/cm3. In each case, the concentration profiles observed had a diffuse character and evolved in time in a manner consistent with Fick's law. However, the experimental diffusivity values varied with protein concentration in the gel and were strongly influenced by the composition of the gel and by the salt concentration in solution. *  Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. Phone:  (804) 924-6281. Fax:  (804) 982-2658. E-mail:  gc@ virginia.edu. IntroductionARTICLE SECTIONSJump ToPolymeric hydrogels have many current and potential applications in biotechnology as a result of their biocompatibility and ability to selectively allow molecules to enter and diffuse on the basis of size. Whereas neutral hydrogels serve as size-exclusion media, incorporation of a fixed charge, bound to the polymer backbone, introduces the ability to concentrate oppositely charged molecules, including macromolecules such as proteins. These solutes can then be released, for example, by changing the ionic strength or the solution pH, by introducing competitive displacers, or, in some cases, by changing temperature or applying electric fields. 1 Potential applications of charged hydrogels include their use as systems for the delivery of therapeutic agents to tissues and cells, 2,3 as components in transdermal delivery of drugs by electroporation and iontophoresis methods, 4,5 as elements in diagnostic application instruments, 6 and as physical models for in vitro studies of partitioning and transport in tissues. 7 Finally, charged hydrogels have important applications in separations based on chromatography and membrane methods. In general, free-standing charged hydrogels undergo large volume changes in response to solution composition changes. This is a desirable property in certain applications including osmotic devices1 and drug delivery systems controlled by the gel swelling rate, 8 as well as in the use of gels as “gel extraction solvents”. 9 Applications to adsorptive and membrane separations are, however, often hampered by this characteristic. Moreover, homogeneous ionic hydrogels that are sufficiently “soft” to enable macromolecule diffusion are subject to mechanical compression when used in chromatography columns or as membranes. Recently, however, ionic hydrogels that are stabilized against mechanical and osmotic forces by being incorporated into rigid porous structures have been developed. For example, composite particles made by incorporating homogeneous, charged polyacrylamide-based gels within the pores of rigid silica or ceramic particles have been described by Girot and Boschetti 10 and have become commercially available with the trade name HyperD as protein chromatography media. 11,12 In these materials, the rigid backbone of the supporting matrix provides structural integrity, while the gel provides a high adsorptive capacity that allows for efficient chromatographic operations at high flow rates of the mobile phase. 13-15 Membranes obtained by synthesizing ionic hydrogels within the pores of rigid filter media have also been developed. Such composite membranes have been shown to retain the hydraulic permeability of equivalent free-standing gels while being largely unaffected by changes in ionic strength. 16Transport rates are, of course, critical in the aforementioned applications, especially for macromolecules. However, whereas diffusional transport of macromolecules in neutral gels is generally well understood both experimentally and theoretically, 17-20 the literature on diffusion of charged macromolecules in oppositely charged ion-exchange gels is scant. In the case of neutral gels, the partition coefficient is typically less than one, and diffusional transport rates are always lower than in free solution as a result of steric and hydrodynamic hindrances. On the other hand, oppositely charged macromolecules can be very favorably partitioned into ionic hydrogels as a result of electrostatic interactions. 21 Thus, although the mobility or diffusion coefficient of these molecules is low compared to that in free solution,  high transport rates can, in principle, be obtained. This effect is well-known for small ions in ion-exchange resins, 22 but it can also be significant for macromolecules in low-density hydrogels. For example, a number of previous studies of protein adsorption in the gel-composite HyperD media have shown that mass transfer is very rapid and, in some cases, it is faster than could be predicted for ordinary diffusion in the bulk liquid phase.15 This behavior has been described in a semiempirical way using a Fickian diffusion model where the driving force is expressed in terms of the adsorbed protein concentration, implying that the protein molecules retain diffusional mobility within the charged gel. From a macroscopic viewpoint, this modeling approach has been found to be consistent with the experimental behavior, thereby allowing for a prediction of performance under ample ranges of conditions and in both batch and packed column systems.14,15,23 In previous work, we developed a technique for a direct microscopic visualization of protein diffusion in charged polyacrylamide-based gels synthesized within fused-silica capillaries, which can provide greater insight into the nature of protein transport in these gels. 24 For ease of microscopic observation, we use capillaries with a square cross section that eliminates optical artifacts. Optically transparent anionic gels can be synthesized in situ, and colored or fluorescent proteins can be used as probes. The evolution of concentration profiles obtained by exposing the end of the capillary-gel composite to a dilute protein solution can thus be followed by direct observation with a microscope. For these conditions, transport can be observed in an essentially semi-infinite, “flat plate” geometry, which simplifies the mathematical analysis of the experimental profiles. For the case of cytochrome c diffusing in an anionic polyacrylamide gel, we observed diffuse concentration profiles consistent with Fick's law. More complicated profiles were seen under desorption conditions when a protein-loaded gel was exposed to a salt solution, suggesting that complex interactions between counter-diffusing ions take place in these ion exchangers. Analysis of the evolution of concentration profiles can obviously provide a direct measurement of diffusivities and is a powerful means of testing hypothesized transport theories. Thus, the objective of this paper is three-fold. The first objective is to determine the effects of boundary-layer mass transfer at the gel−fluid interface. Because transport in the gel can be rapid, the fluid-phase resistance can become significant at low protein concentrations. Hence, its effect needs to be determined. The second objective is to determine the reversibility of the mass-transfer process under protein binding conditions. In particular, we are interested in exploring what happens when the protein concentration is reduced to zero in the bulk fluid following an initial loading of the gel from a more concentrated protein solution. Finally, the third objective is to determine the protein diffusivity in the gel as a function of polymer concentration, polymer charge density, and salt concentration in solution. For each of these variables, concentration profiles were obtained under transient adsorption or desorption conditions using cytochrome c as the probe. The experimental profiles were analyzed in terms of a model that incorporates the fluid-phase resistance and an empirically determined concentration-dependent diffusivity in the gel. Experimental SectionARTICLE SECTIONSJump ToMaterials. The materials used in the preparation of gels were 2-acrylamido-2-methylpropane sulfonic acid (AMPS, 98% purity), N,N‘-methylene bisacrylamide (MBA, 98% purity), ammonium persulfate (AP), N,N,N,N-tetraethylenediamine (TEMED), and acrylamide. These materials were obtained from Lancaster Synthesis Inc. (Windham, NH) and Sigma Chemical Co. (St. Louis, MO). Bind-silane (γ-methacryloxypropyltrimethoxysilane) was obtained from Pharmacia (Piscataway, NJ). Cytochrome c from bovine heart (Mr = 13 300, pI = 10.6) was obtained from Sigma Chemical Co. Other chemicals were obtained from Sigma Chemical Co. or Fisher Scientific (Pittsburgh, PA). Fused-silica, polyimide-coated capillary tubing with a square cross section was obtained from Polymicro Technologies, Inc. (Phoenix, AZ). This tubing has a nearly perfect square cross section with internal and external widths of 100 and 300 μm, respectively. The tubing was cut into approximately 1-cm sections, and the polymer coating was burned off from the top 0.5−0.6 cm. The sections were then treated with bind-silane as described by Lewus and Carta24 to provide a way of anchoring the polyacrylamide gel by covalent attachment to the capillary. Preparation of Gels. The procedure used to prepare the capillary-constrained gels used in this work is described in detail by Lewus and Carta24 and is similar to the methods described by Girot and Boschetti10 for the preparation of gel-composite particles. Thus, only the main steps are described here. A monomer mixture is first prepared in filtered, degassed water by dissolving the AMPS monomer and the MBA cross-linker in the desired proportion. After the solution is titrated to pH 7 with NaOH, the volume is adjusted to the desired value with additional water. The AP initiator and the TEMED promoter are then added and stirred into the solution. The reaction mixture is then quickly loaded into the capillary sections and allowed to polymerize at room temperature. Upon completion of the polymerization (∼1 h), the capillaries are placed into a large volume of 10 mM Na2HPO4 buffer at pH 6.5 for at least 24 h. The composition and basic properties of a “standard” gel used in this work are summarized in Table 1. Gels with different polymer concentrations were obtained by varying the total concentration of the monomer solution while maintaining the same ratio of AMPS and MBA. Conversely, gels with the same polymer concentration and cross-linking ratio but with different charge densities were obtained by substituting acrylamide for the AMPS monomer in the initial mixture. Microscopic observation of the capillaries after equilibration in the buffer revealed that minimal volume change occurred, as the gel was covalently bound to the ligands at the inner surface of the capillary. The charge density, based on the gel volume, can thus be estimated from the composition of the polymerization mixture. The polymer volume fraction φ = mpvp/(mpvp + mwvw) was estimated from the initial monomer composition using a value of vp = 0.7 cm3/g for the polymer density, as suggested by Kapur et al. 25 Table 1.  Composition of Standard Gel Used in This Workpolymer concentration 0.21 g/cm3cross-link density 5% g/g charge density 970 μequiv/cm3φ 0.15 v/vThe degree of incorporation of the monomers in the gels prepared in this work was estimated by filling  several test tubes with 5 cm3 of a monomer mixture with the composition in Table 1 and allowing the polymerization to proceed. After 1 h, the gel was removed from each test tube, cut into small pieces 1−2 mm in size, and placed into a 200 cm3 volume of buffer solution for 48 h to remove any potentially unreacted monomer. The gel particles were recovered by filtration through filter paper; rinsed with distilled, deionized water; and then dried in an oven at 120 °C for 48 h. The weight of dried polymer was determined and compared with the initial weight of monomer loaded into each test tube. The results gave a 98 ± 0.5% recovery of the initial monomer weight, which is within the monomer purity stated by the supplier. This determination confirms that essentially all of the monomer is incorporated in the gel. Similar results have been obtained by Gelfi and Righetti, 26 who, using a different method, determined that acrylamide−bisacrylamide gels with a 5% cross-link density are fully polymerized within 30 min at room temperature. Measurement of Concentration Profiles. A schematic of the diffusion cell used in this work is shown in Figure 1. The cell was realized by sandwiching a 1/8-in.-thick Teflon slab between two microscope slides as described in detail by Lewus and Carta.24 One end of a capillary tube section prepared as described above was sealed by gluing it to the tip of a syringe needle with a cyanoacrylate adhesive. The needle was then inserted into the cell. The protein solution was allowed to flow in to and out of the cell through stainless steel tubes (1/32-in. o.d., 1/64-in. i.d.) and recirculated with a peristaltic pump (Cole-Parmer Instrument Co., Chicago, IL) at a flow rate of 0.5 cm3/min. Two flow configurations were used, as shown in Figure 1. In the parallel-flow configuration, the solution flow is perpendicular to the capillary. In this case, the velocity past the tip of the capillary has the same magnitude as the mean velocity in the flow channel, or about 0.033 cm/s (120 cm/h) for our experimental conditions. This velocity is comparable to values typically used in packed columns for preparative protein chromatography. In the impinging-flow configuration, the inlet tube is positioned at a distance of approximately 3 mm from the tip of the capillary. Thus, in this case, the approach velocity is similar to the mean velocity in the feed tubing, or about 7.8 cm/s (28 000 cm/h) for our experimental conditions. The vastly different velocities obtained in the two configurations should result in highly different boundary-layer mass-transfer-resistance effects.  Figure 1 Schematic of cells used for diffusion studies.High Resolution ImageDownload MS PowerPoint SlideThe evolution of concentration profiles in the gel was followed by direct observation with a microscope, as described by Lewus and Carta.24 Cytochrome c is intensely colored (reddish-brown) and is favorably partitioned in these gels at low ionic strength. 27 Thus, diffusional transport in the gel can be characterized by direct visual observation. Gray-scale values of the digitized images were obtained using the public domain NIH Image program (developed at the U.S. National Institutes of Health and available on the Internet at http://rsb.info.nih.gov/nih-image/) and were converted to protein concentrations in the gel using a calibration curve obtained by determining the gray scale for identical capillaries filled with cytochrome c solutions of different concentrations.24The equilibrium binding capacity of the gels for cytochrome c was also determined. To obtain these data, capillary tubes prepared as discussed above were suspended in cytochrome c solutions of known concentrations. After 72 h, the capillaries were placed into the flow cell, and images were recorded. The gray-scale level of the saturated gel was then used to determine the equilibrium binding capacity. At low protein concentrations, however, external mass transfer under stagnant conditions was so slow that equilibrium was not established even after 72 h. Thus, at protein concentrations of 0.1 and 0.25 mg/cm3, the capacity was determined by allowing the tubes to come to equilibrium under flow conditions in the diffusion cell. The equilibrium binding capacity was also determined through a direct measurement by equilibrating several capillary tubes in a 1 mg/cm3 cytochrome c solution and then eluting the protein by immersing the tubes in a known volume of a 500 mM buffered NaCl solution. For these conditions, the protein was completely desorbed. Hence, the amount of protein initially bound could be calculated from a material balance based on the analytical determination of the concentration of the desorbed protein in the salt buffer. The latter was done by measuring the absorbance at 405 nm with a spectrophotometer (Beckman, model DU50). All experiments were conducted at room temperature, 23 ± 2 °C, in a 10 mM Na2HPO4 buffer at pH 6.5. ResultsARTICLE SECTIONSJump ToProtein Adsorption Equilibrium. The protein binding isotherm for the standard gel having the composition given in Table 1 is shown in Figure 2. The maximum capacity is in excess of 400 mg/cm3, which is in agreement with the value of 410 ± 80 mg/cm3 obtained independently by measuring the amount of protein desorbed, as discussed in the Experimental Section. This value is consistent with the high protein binding capacity values observed for commercial HyperD particles27 and is a result of the high charge density of the gel and the apparent accessibility of the charged groups. Assuming a value of 0.7 cm3/g for the specific volume of the protein, 28 the measured protein binding capacity corresponds to a volume fraction of protein in the gel of 0.29 ± 0.06, indicating that protein  binding must occur through a three-dimensional filling of the polymer gel network. The isotherm data were empirically represented by the Toth isotherm, which has the form where q* and C are the adsorbed and fluid-phase equilibrium protein concentrations, respectively; and qm, b, and n are fitting parameters. The parameter values determined from a nonlinear least-squares fit of the data are qm = 450 mg/cm3, b = 7.7 cm3/mg, and n = 1.3. The calculated isotherm line is shown in Figure 2. Binding capacities at different salt concentrations were also determined, but only at a cytochrome c concentration of 1 mg/cm3. These results are presented later. Digitized images of the evolution of the cytochrome c concentration profiles during adsorption in a gel with the composition described in Table 1 under impinging flow conditions are shown in Figure 3, along with calibrated profiles normalized with respect to the equilibrium capacity, q*. Approximately 1 mm of capillary tube is visible in these images. The lightly colored area surrounding the capillary corresponds to the 1 mg/cm3 cytochrome c solution used in this experiment. The dark red band seen progressing toward the left corresponds to the cytochrome c penetration into the gel. The favorable partioning of cytochrome c in the gel for these conditions is evident from the large contrast in red intensity between the solution and gel phases. Some imperfections clearly exist near the cut end of the capillary, and the gel is seen to protrude slightly beyond the boundaries of the fused-silica tube. However, because the times of the observations were quite long and the depth of penetration of cytochrome c was substantial, these imperfections at the boundary should be of limited significance in the interpretation of the results. Concentration gradients in the direction transverse to the capillary also appear to be absent. From gray-scale analysis of the digitized images, variations in this direction were very small (<5%), except in the region immediately adjacent to the walls where shadowing prevented an accurate determination of the concentration. These regions, amounting to less than 10% of the total width, were, of course, not used to calculate the axial concentration profiles. Both the digitized images and the calibrated profiles show that the cytochrome c band in the gel has a smooth, diffuse nature, with the concentration in the gel gradually declining from a maximum at the exposed tip of the capillary to zero toward the unexposed end. Profiles are shown at 0.5, 1, 2, and 4 h.High Resolution ImageDownload MS PowerPoint SlideMathematical Analysis of Concentration Profiles. A mathematical analysis based on a Fickian diffusion model with a concentration-dependent diffusivity Ds(q) was used to treat the experimental concentration profiles. No assumption regarding the form of the Ds(q) function was made, as it can be determined directly from the experimental profiles, as follows. Initially neglecting the fluid-phase resistance, the conservation equation and boundary conditions for uniaxial diffusion into a semi-infinite slab can be written as where q0 and qs are, respectively, the initial and interfacial protein concentrations in the gel. The latter is given by the adsorption isotherm. Inspection of the experimental profiles shown in Figure 3 confirms that these boundary conditions are compatible with the experimental system. This occurs because, for these conditions, equilibrium is achieved rapidly (compared to the time scale of the experiment) at the exposed tip of the capillary and the concentration profile is not allowed to extend to the opposite end. It should be noted that eq 2 assumes a diffusional driving force written in terms of the adsorbed-phase protein concentration gradient. Applying the Boltzmann transformation to eq 2 yields the ordinary differential equation where Finally, integrating eq 3 from η = ∞ to η yields which can be used to calculate the diffusivity as a function of concentration directly from the experimental profiles. As an example, Figure 4a shows the data of Figure 3 plotted as a function of η for times of 0.5−4 h. The region near the exposed tip of the capillary, where some artifacts exist, is omitted from this graph and was not used in these calculations. The collapse of the profiles for different times onto essentially a single curve supports the validity of the approach. To perform the integral and derivative calculations needed for eq 5, the experimental profiles at each time in the form of η vs q were fitted with a smooth function. Integral and derivative terms were then computed analytically. Typical results are shown in Figure 4b. For this case, the experimental diffusivity remains fairly constant as a function of protein concentration in the gel and has an average value of 4 × 10-8 cm2/s. Although the diffusivity value is many times smaller than the diffusivity of cytochrome c in solution (D0 = 1 × 10-6 cm2/s), the rate of mass transfer was actually very high. In fact, for these conditions, because the isotherm is very favorable, an equivalent diffusivity D̃ based on a driving force expressed as a gradient in fluid-phase concentration can be calculated as15 The resulting value is approximately 16 times higher than the free solution diffusivity, indicating that protein transport through this gel occurs at a much higher rate than could be expected for fluid-phase diffusion alone. High Resolution ImageDownload MS PowerPoint SlideEffects of Boundary-Layer Resistance. The preceding analysis of concentration profiles was based on the assumption that equilibrium is established rapidly at the exposed end of the gel. Mass transfer to the surface of the gel can be expected to be high because of the high velocity flow of the protein solution past the capillary tube in the impinging-flow configuration. However, because, as discussed above, transport in the gel is fast, under certain conditions, the external film could still offer a limiting resistance. A qualitative criterion for determination of the importance of the external resistance during adsorption can be based on the magnitude of the dimensionless group where λ is the mean depth of penetration of the protein profile in the gel and kf is the boundary-layer mass-transfer coefficient. The external resistance is dominant when δ is less than 1. This occurs for short times (λ → 0) and for large values of the partition ratio q*/C, i.e., for low protein solution concentrations. Moreover, because kf increases with fluid velocity, the external resistance is likely to be more important in the parallel-flow configuration. Concentration profiles obtained for the adsorption of cytochrome c in the parallel-flow configuration of the diffusion cell at 1 and 0.25 mg/cm3 are shown in Figure 5. At 1 mg/cm3 protein concentration, the profiles appear to extrapolate fairly well to the same interfacial value of q/q* = 1, indicating that, for these conditions, the external resistance plays only a small role. However, this is not the case at 0.25 mg/cm3 protein concentration. In this case, the profiles extrapolate to q/q* = 1 only at long times. As shown in Figure 6, the same behavior at the interface is also observed for the impinging-flow configuration but at the substantially lower protein solution concentration of 0.1 mg/cm3. In this case, boundary condition 2a in the model equation is replaced by where C and Cs are the protein solution concentrations in the bulk and at the surface of the gel, respectively. The empirical Toth isotherm was used to relate Cs and qs. Numerically computed profiles obtained from the solution of eq 2 with eqs 7, 2b, and 2c as boundary conditions and using the experimental dependence of Dsobtained from the impinging-flow experiment at a protein concentration of 1 mg/cm3 were compared with the experimental profiles in Figures 5b and 6 for different values of kf. The solution was obtained by finite differences, as described in Lewus. 29 Best-fit values were kf = (2.0 ± 0.5) × 10-3 cm/s for parallel flow and kf = (9 ± 0.5) × 10-3 cm/s for impinging flow. As expected, the latter value is substantially higher as the boundary-layer thickness is likely to be much smaller in impinging  flow. 30 The corresponding Sherwood number values, based on the width of the gel capillaries, are Sh = 20 and Sh = 90 for parallel and impinging flow, respectively. Calculated profiles using the best-fit kf values are shown in Figures 3, 5, and 6. In all cases, the calculated profiles are within the accuracy of the experimental determinations. It is noteworthy that the fitted kf values predict the correct trend with respect to protein solution concentration. In fact, in agreement with the experimental trends, the effect of kf is very small at 1 mg/cm3 in parallel flow (Figure 5a) and insignificant at 1 mg/cm3 in impinging flow (Figure 3). The second case considered for comparison with predicted profiles involves a situation in which the gel is exposed to protein-free buffer after having been exposed to 1 mg/cm3 cytochrome c for 4 h. In this case, because the isotherm is favorable, desorption of protein from the gel is expected to be limited largely by the external mass-transfer resistance. This occurs because the protein concentration in the fluid phase adjacent to the exposed end of the gel is kept very low by the favorable nature of the isotherm. As a result, the driving force for external transport is low, and the effect of kf should be dominant. Experimental and predicted profiles are shown in Figure 7 for a gel with the composition described in Table 1. During the first 0.5 h after the protein concentration is decreased to zero in solution, the protein concentration in the gel near the tip of the capillary is reduced by more than 20%. However, the protein clearly continues to diffuse into the gel. As time progresses, the protein moves further into the gel, while the concentration at the tip decreases slowly. It is apparent that a small amount of protein is desorbed from the gel, which explains the maximum in the profiles. The predicted profiles, obtained using eqs 2, 7, 2b, and 2c with kf = 2 × 10-3 cm/s, slightly overestimate the rate, indicating that the protein might experience a small additional resistance to transport as it “detaches” from the gel. However, in general, the model predicts the experimental trends accurately without adjustment of any of the parameter values. Profiles shown at 0, 0.5, 1, 2, and 4 h.High Resolution ImageDownload MS PowerPoint SlideEffects of Gel Properties. It is well-established that polymer properties can strongly affect diffusion and partitioning of proteins in neutral gels (e.g., refs 20 and 31−33). Studies on the effects of polymer properties for protein diffusion in ionic gels, however, have been rather limited. Here, we consider the effects of the cross-link density, the polymer concentration, and the charge density of the gel on cytochrome c diffusion and partitioning. Effect of Cross-Link Density. The effect of cross-link density on cytochrome c transport was considered previously by Lewus and Carta24 for capillary-constrained gels with the composition of Table 1, who varied the degree of cross-linking from 2.5 to 10% while maintaining a constant total polymer concentration in the monomer mixture. A 30% increase in the cytochrome c diffusivity was obtained when the extent of cross-linking was reduced from 10 to 5%. However, further reduction of the degree of cross-linking to 2.5% had a  smaller effect. This behavior is quite different from that expected for a free-standing gel where the polymer concentration is inversely related to the cross-link density. In our case, because the gel is synthesized in situ in a confined volume, the polymer concentration remains essentially constant for different cross-link densities. This is consistent with the observations of Kapur et al.16 for gels supported in porous membranes. A summary of our data on the effects of the cross-link density is given in Figure 8a. To facilitate a comparison of different gels, we define a limiting diffusivity, Ds*, obtained by extrapolating the Ds(q) data to q = q*. The latter is shown, along with the partition ratio, K = q*/C. In addition, to provide a comparison of the overall rate of adsorption, we also calculated the total amount of protein adsorbed in a 4-h period, and this is shown in Figure 8b. As seen in these figures, although the partitioning of the protein in the gel increases slightly as the degree of cross-linking is increased, the diffusivity is reduced more substantially. As a result, the amount of protein adsorbed declines slightly.  Figure 8 Effect of cross-link density. (a) Diffusivity and partition ratio. (b) Total protein adsorbed in 4 h. The polymer concentration was varied by altering the amount of monomer and cross-linker present in the gel while maintaining their ratio constant. Five different polymer concentrations were tested:  0.05, 0.11, 0.21, 0.32, and 0.42 g/cm3. At a polymer concentration of 0.42 g/cm3, very little penetration of cytochrome c in the gel could be detected.24 However, different results were obtained at the other concentrations considered in this work. Concentration profiles for a polymer concentration of 0.11 g/cm3 are shown in Figure 9, along with the diffusivities as a function of adsorbed cytochrome c concentration for the range 0.05−0.32 g/cm3. Ds in each case varies with the adsorbed-phase concentration. On average, however, the diffusivity has the highest values at 0.11 g/cm3 and is lower at both higher and lower polymer concentrations. Calculated profiles using the fitted Ds(q) data are shown in Figure 9 and are in good agreement with the experimental profiles. Figure 10 shows a summary of the effects of polymer concentration on partitioning and transport. In this case, both the diffusivity and the partition ratio have a maximum at intermediate polymer concentrations. This is also true for the amount of protein adsorbed in 4 h, which combines the effects of Ds and K. For these conditions, the adsorption rate appears to have a maximum at a protein concentration of around 0.1 g/cm3. Protein concentration = 1 mg/cm3.High Resolution ImageDownload MS PowerPoint SlideIt is of interest to compare the results obtained for cytochrome c in our charged gels with the partition coefficient, KD, for a neutral spherical molecule of the same size as this protein. Obviously, in the absence of attractive interactions between this molecule and the gel, KD is less than 1 because of size-exclusion effects. Assuming that the polymer gel can be represented as a matrix of long cylindrical fibers of radius rf, KD can be estimated from the expression17,33 where rs is the molecule radius. For cytochrome c, rs is estimated to be 2.1 nm from diffusion data. For polyacrylamide gels, values of rf between 0.325 and 0.65 nm have been suggested. 33-36 Although these values can  only be used as rough approximations for our AMPS-based gels, they still provide useful insight. Table 2 shows the calculated values of φ and KD for our constrained gels with different polymer concentrations using the estimate of rf = 0.65 nm, along with the measured partition ratio, K, for cytochrome c. It is apparent that, for a polymer concentration of 0.42 g/cm3, nearly complete exclusion of an equivalently sized neutral molecule is obtained. As the polymer concentration is reduced, the mesh size becomes sufficiently large to permit favorable partitioning and rapid diffusion. However, as the polymer concentration is reduced further, the charge density decreases to the point where partitioning becomes much less favorable and a much smaller partition ratio is attained. We can conclude that the size-exclusion effects of the polymer gel can be overcome by the attractive interaction between the protein and the charged groups, but only up to a point where size exclusion becomes dominant. For example, a gel with the standard composition of Table 1, although effective in adsorbing cytochrome c, would become ineffective for a larger protein. This was verified experimentally using hemoglobin. This protein has an effective radius rs ≈ 3.5 nm, which gives a corresponding value of KD = 0.002. Protein concentration = 1 mg/cm3.High Resolution ImageDownload MS PowerPoint SlideEffect of Ionic Strength. The final effect considered is that of the ionic strength of the solution. In a free-standing ionic gel, this effect can be dramatic, as the gel volume can change substantially as the ionic strength  is varied. However, in our case, gel volume variations were absent. To investigate the effect of salt concentration on diffusion and partitioning, experiments were done with the standard gel with the composition of Table 1 using 1 mg/cm3 cytochrome c solutions containing different concentrations of NaCl. Figure 13 shows the concentration profiles obtained at 50 mM NaCl and the calculated Ds values as a function of q/q*, and Figure 14 shows the dependence of Ds* and K on salt concentration. Curves calculated using the fitted Ds(q) values are also shown in Figure 13. The general trends with regard to the shape of the concentration profiles remain similar as the salt concentration is increased. However, the diffusivity gradually increases, while the partition ratio decreases sharply. This behavior can be explained by the fact that the presence of salt reduces the electrostatic interaction between the protein and the gel's ionogenic groups while increasing the flexibility of the gel through decreased electrostatic repulsion between the polymer chains. The combination of these two effects leads to greater diffusional mobility but also reduces partitioning. The effect on partitioning is much more pronounced than the effect on diffusivity. Thus, the net effect is that the amount adsorbed in 4 h decreases as the salt concentration is increased. (b) Total protein adsorbed in 4 h. Protein concentration = 1 mg/cm3.High Resolution ImageDownload MS PowerPoint SlideComparison with Gels Supported in Porous Particles. An important consideration is a comparison of the results obtained in this work with those previously obtained for commercial HyperD media where charged hydrogels similar to those used here are supported not by a straight capillary but by the randomly oriented and tortuous pore network of silica particles. Table 3 gives the relevant properties for the anionic S-HyperD particles as determined by Lewus and Carta.27 The effects of the adsorptively inert support matrix in these particles can be taken into account in the classical way by defining “corrected” properties calculated on a “per gel volume” basis using the support porosity εp ≈ 0.6 and an assumed tortuosity factor τp = 4 for the pore network.36 Thus, for example, the corrected charge density of S-HyperD is (200 μequiv/cm3)/0.6 = 330 μequiv/cm3, and the corrected diffusivity of cytochrome c is (1 × 10-8 cm2/s) × (4/0.6) ≈ 7 × 10-8 cm2/s. The properties of a comparable gel synthesized with the same charge density are also given in Table 3. As seen in this table, the gels with the same charge density also have nearly the same protein uptake capacity for cytochrome c and similar average diffusivities. In addition, similar trends have also been observed for S-HyperD particles with respect to the effect of protein concentration on the boundary-layer mass-transfer resistance15,27 and with respect to the effect of salt concentration on diffusion rates in the particles. 37 This suggests that predictions for gels supported in pores of typical support matrixes can be made using the results in this work within the range of accuracy normally expected for the simple classical tortuosity factor approach. Diffuse concentration profiles that are consistent with a Fickian diffusion model in which the driving force is expressed  in terms of the gradient in adsorbed protein concentration are observed. Because of the rapid rate of protein transport in these gels, boundary-layer mass-transfer limitations become important in our experimental system for certain conditions. These effects are taken into account in a model developed in this work that predicts transient adsorption at both low and high protein concentrations, as well as desorption, when mass transfer out of the gel becomes nearly completely dominated by the external resistance. The effects of gel composition and ionic strength on partitioning and transport have been determined. The effect of cross-link density over the range 2.5−10% is small compared to what could be expected for free-standing gels, because in our constrained gels, the volume remains essentially constant as the cross-link density is varied. The effect of polymer concentration is, however, rather dramatic. As the polymer concentration is increased, the effective mesh size decreases. Thus, although the charge density increases with polymer concentration, as the polymer concentration is gradually increased, a point is reached at which size exclusion becomes dominant and both partitioning and transport are dramatically reduced. A maximum rate is obtained at intermediate polymer concentrations. Increasing charge density while keeping a constant polymer concentration has the effect of increasing partitioning but decreasing diffusivity. As a result, a maximum rate is again observed at intermediate charge densities. Adding NaCl to the protein solution does not change the qualitative trends of the diffusion profiles. However, partitioning of the protein is substantially reduced, while a moderate increase in diffusivity occurs. As a result, adsorption rates are maximized at low ionic strengths. In summary, although a theory to predict the behavior of proteins in oppositely charged ionic gels is not yet available, the data obtained in this work can provide a basis for the design of separation media with optimized properties. Further results for cationic gels and for multicomponent transport situations will be the subject of future communications. Author InformationARTICLE SECTIONSJump ToAuthorsRebecca K.         Permeable large-pore particles have many applications, in particular in perfusion chromatog. for biosepns.  The objective of this paper is to elucidate the mass transport mechanisms in two com. adsorbents, POROS Q/M and Q Hyper D, and to answer the question if intraparticle convection is present as a mass transfer mechanism.  In the first part of the paper, mass transfer inside porous particles is discussed.  The mass transfer mechanism which allows improved performance of perfusion chromatog. is intraparticle convection.  The combined effect of intraparticle convection and diffusion is an "augmented" effective diffusivity.  This is the key concept to explain the peak sharpening and modified Van Demeter plots found with large-pore particles.  In the second part, column efficiencies in terms of HETP as a function of bed superficial velocity are exptl. measured for a non-retained protein (bovine serum albumin [BSA]) in two adsorbents: POROS Q/M (PerSeptive Biosystems) and Q Hyper D (BioSepra).  In the third section, breakthrough curves for both materials are measured for a test protein (BSA) from which useful capacities and productivities as a function of flow-rate are calcd.  Exptl. results indicate that intraparticle convection plays indeed an important role in both adsorbents. >> More from SciFinder ®https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2MXjsFamtb8%253D&md5=7d25bc0e0a13ef5d1e61ca0323c5372a14Fernandez, M.         Solute diffusion in hydrogels is important in many biotechnol. fields.  Solute behavior in hydrogels has been explained in terms of redn. in hydrogel free vol., enhanced hydrodynamic drag on the solute, increased path length due to obstruction, and a combination of hydrodynamic drag and obstruction effects.  In this article the various math. models derived to explain and predict solute diffusion in hydrogels are discussed and tested against literature data.  These models can be divided into those applicable to hydrogels composed of flexible polymer chains (i.e., homogeneous hydrogels) and those composed of rigid polymer chains (i.e., heterogeneous hydrogels).  For homogeneous hydrogels it was detd. that a scaling hydrodynamic model provided the best explanation for solute diffusion, while for heterogeneous hydrogels obstruction models were more consistent with the exptl. data.  Both the scaling hydrodynamic model and the most appropriate obstruction model contain undefined parameters which must be clarified in order for these models to gain widespread acceptance. >> More from SciFinder ®https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXms1Kns74%253D&md5=dc41c3a5a06648497caf7dc2f273133519Boyer, P. The rate of diffusion and convection (ultrafiltration) of two proteins, RNase A (RNAse) and bovine serum albumin (BSA), was measured as a function of the amt. of gel in the pores expressed as the vol. fraction (.vphi.) occupied by the polymer forming the gel network.  The diffusion rate of potassium chloride (KCl) and glucose was also measured to det. the effects of the gel on small mols.  The effective diffusion coeff. (Deff), normalized by the diffusion coeff. in bulk soln. (Do), and the reflection coeff. (.vsigma.) were correlated with the parameter (as/af).vphi. where as is the Stokes-Einstein radius of the solute mol. and af is the radius of the PA chains (6Å) forming the gel network inside the pores.  Both Deff/Do and 1-.vsigma. decreased sharply as (as/af).vphi. approached the value 0.6.  The gel had only a small effect on the diffusion of KCl and glucose.         The equil. partition coeff. (K) and diffusion coeff. (Dgel) of 2 proteins and 2 linear polymers were measured as a function of polymer content of a 2.7% cross-linked polyacrylamide (PA) gel.  The gel concn., expressed as a vol. percentage of PA in the gel (.vphi.), varied between 0-14%.  The measurements were made by fluorescence spectroscopy; fluorescent dyes were covalently attached to the macromols.  The dependence of K on .vphi. for the proteins agrees with a model of the gel network as randomly placed, impenetrable rods.  The diffusion data are interpreted in terms of an effective medium theory for the mobility of a sphere in a Brinkman fluid.  Using values of the Brinkman parameter in the literature, the effective medium model with no adjustable parameters fits the diffusion data for the proteins very well but under predicts Dgel for the linear polymers. The objective of this paper is to elucidate the mass transport mechanisms in two com. adsorbents, POROS Q/M and Q Hyper D, and to answer the question if intraparticle convection is present as a mass transfer mechanism.  In the first part of the paper, mass transfer inside porous particles is discussed.  The mass transfer mechanism which allows improved performance of perfusion chromatog. is intraparticle convection.         Solute diffusion in hydrogels is important in many biotechnol. fields.  Solute behavior in hydrogels has been explained in terms of redn. in hydrogel free vol., enhanced hydrodynamic drag on the solute, increased path length due to obstruction, and a combination of hydrodynamic drag and obstruction effects.  In this article the various math. models derived to explain and predict solute diffusion in hydrogels are discussed and tested against literature data.  These models can be divided into those applicable to hydrogels composed of flexible polymer chains (i.e., homogeneous hydrogels) and those composed of rigid polymer chains (i.e., heterogeneous hydrogels). Unfolding and aggregation of monoclonal antibodies on cation exchange columns: Effects of resin type, load buffer, and protein stability - ScienceDirect















      JavaScript is disabled on your browser.

ScienceDirectJournals & BooksHelpSearchInstitutionRegisterSign in PDFView PDFDownload Full IssueSearchJournal of Chromatography AVolume 1388, 3 April 2015, Pages 184-194Unfolding and aggregation of monoclonal antibodies on cation exchange columns: Effects of resin type, load buffer, and protein stabilityAuthor links open overlay panelJingGuoGiorgioCartaPersonEnvelopeShow moreNavigate DownPlusAdd to MendeleyShareShareCited ByCitehttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.chroma.2015.02.047Get rights and contentHighlights•mAb two-peak elution behavior occurs on various CEX resins.•Effect is pronounced for polymer-grafted resins and absent for macroporous resins.•HX-MS shows that unfolding of the bound mAb is the cause.•Counterion type and pH have large effects on the two-peak elution behavior.•Arginine in the load step eliminates unfolding and the two-peak elution behavior.AbstractThe chromatographic behavior of a monoclonal antibody (mAb) that exhibits a pronounced two-peak elution behavior is studied for a range of strong cation exchange resins and with varying load buffer pH and composition. Six stationary phases are considered, including two tentacle-type resins (Fractogel EMD SO3-(M) and Eshmuno S), a resin with grafted polymeric surface extenders (Nuvia S), a resin with a bimodal pore size distribution (POROS HS 50), and two macroporous resins without polymer grafts (Source 30S and UNOsphere Rapid S). The two-peak elution behavior is very pronounced for the tentacle and polymer-grafted resins and for POROS HS 50, but is essentially absent for the two macroporous resins. The extent of this behavior decreases as the buffer pH and concentration increase and, consequently, mAb binding becomes weaker. Replacing sodium with arginine as the buffer counterion, which is expected to decrease the mAb binding strength, nearly completely eliminates the two-peak behavior, while replacing sodium with tetra-n-butylammonium hydroxide, which is expected to increase the mAb binding strength, dramatically exacerbate the effect. As shown by hydrogen–deuterium exchange mass spectrometry (HX-MS), the two-peak elution behavior is related to conformational changes that occur when the mAb binds. These changes result in increased solvent exposure of specific peptides in the Fc-region for either the Fractogel or the Nuvia resin. No significant conformational changes were seen by HX-MS when the mAb was bound to the UNOsphere resin or on the Fractogel resin when arginine was used in lieu of sodium as the load buffer counterion. Experiments with two additional mAbs on the Fractogel resin show that the two-peak elution behavior is dependent on the particular antibody. Circular dichroism suggests that the propensity of different mAbs to either precipitate directly or to form stabilizing intermolecular structures upon exposure to thermal stress can be related to their chromatographic behaviors.Navigate LeftPrevious article in issueNext article in issueNavigate RightKeywordsMonoclonal antibodiesCation exchangeUnfoldingAggregationHydrogen–deuterium exchange mass spectrometryCircular dichroismRecommended articlesCited by (0)View AbstractCopyright © 2015 Elsevier B.V.
