Get e-AlertsAbstractAdsorption and desorption rates of lysozyme onto gel-filled rigid particles for ion-exchange chromatography are measured. The adsorbent medium, known as S-HyperD, comprises polystyrene-coated silica particles whose pores are filled with a functionalized poly(acrylamide)-based hydrogel. The equilibrium uptake decreases gradually with salt concentration in the range 0−150 mM, and no uptake occurs at concentrations of 300 mM or greater. In the low salt range, the rates are consistent with a homogeneous diffusion model where the driving force is the bound protein concentration gradient. As a result of highly favorable partitioning in the gel, transport rates are higher than predicted for diffusion in liquid-filled pores. At high salt concentrations, the measured rates are still consistent with the model, but the diffusivity is higher. In all cases, intraparticle transport is independent of hydrodynamics. The behavior of cyclic column operations is successfully predicted using this model. *  To whom correspondence should be addressed. Telephone:  (804) 924 6281. Fax:  (804) 982 2658. E-mail:  gc@virginia.edu.IntroductionARTICLE SECTIONSJump ToRecently, there has been considerable interest in the development of high-capacity ion-exchange media suitable for the recovery of proteins from dilute solutions in packed beds operated at elevated flow rates of the mobile phase (Boschetti, 1994). Operating at high speed often has the advantage of higher productivity and may result in improved product recovery as a result of the shorter processing time. A key issue in the development of such media is to be able to balance matrix properties that lead to high adsorption capacities with those that lead to a mechanical strength sufficient to allow operation with small particle sizes at high flow rates. Functionalized “soft” hydrogels, such as polyacrylamide and dextran, can be designed to exhibit high capacities and may exhibit rapid diffusional kinetics. However they are compressible and swell or shrink in response to ionic strength changes. Conversely, rigid porous media, such as silica and polystyrene−DVB matrixes, while capable of withstanding high compressive forces, do not usually have a high adsorption capacity, since the pore size and hence the surface area are constrained by the large size of typical proteins. It has been suggested (Boschetti, 1994) that recently developed gel-composite media can overcome these limitations. Such materials are obtained by incorporating a hydrogel, which provides ion-exchange sites for interaction with the protein, within a rigid matrix, which provides mechanical strength and resistance to swelling and shrinking. In previous work (Fernandez and Carta, 1996; Fernandez et al., 1996; Weaver and Carta, 1996), we have characterized the uptake equilibria and rates of adsorption of several proteins at low ionic strengths on commercially available gel-composite media known by the trade name HyperD (BioSepra, Inc., Marlborough, MA). These materials have high uptake capacities for typical proteins of about 200−300 mg/cm3 of media. More importantly, they exhibit rapid uptake kinetics. In fact, under conditions favoring binding, mass transfer rates are faster than would be predicted for identical particles in the absence of gel. This effect has been attributed to the nature of the diffusion process in these materials. At low salt concentrations, we have found that mass transfer rates in these particles are consistent with a diffusion model where the driving force is expressed in terms of the bound protein concentration. Since the latter is typically much larger than the external solution concentration, the diffusion flux in the gel-filled pores can be much larger than it would be for diffusion in fluid filled pores, due to the extremely favorable partitioning of binding proteins. As a result of high equilibrium capacity, favorable mass transfer kinetics, and mechanically stable configuration of the particles, high dynamic binding capacities are obtained in columns even at mobile phase flow rates exceeding 7000 cm/hr (Fernandez et al., 1996; Weaver and Carta, 1996). Although low-salt conditions are typical in a protein-capture step, an understanding of equilibrium and transport rates under varying salt concentrations is needed to describe other chromatographic steps and processes. Moreover, a knowledge of the rate of desorption is necessary to describe a complete process. Salt, in fact, is used to recover adsorbed protein in frontal chromatography and to modulate the separation in gradient elution chromatography (Yamamoto et al., 1988). Transport rates in ion exchangers under conditions favoring desorption of the protein, in particular, have been considered only by a few authors in the prior literature. Tsou and Graham (1985), for example, considered adsorption and desorption of protein on dextran-based ion exchangers in batch contactors, but their work was limited to a highly swellable resin and did not address a prediction of desorption rates in columns. Graham and Fook (1982) also considered adsorption and desorption rates for cellulose-based ion exchangers in batch contactors and used an approximate two-film model to describe the effects of external and intraparticle diffusional limitations. Finally, a limited study on the desorption rate of proteins from a polymer-coated silica-based ion exchanger by van der Wiel (1989) showed that the salt-induced desorption rate of protein can be described properly if all the protein is  assumed to be released instantaneously from the pore wall and then to diffuse through the pores. In this work, we have investigated the rates of adsorption and desorption of lysozyme on S-HyperD (BioSepra, Inc., Marlborough, MA) at different salt concentrations. Experimental data are obtained both in an agitated vessel and in a shallow-bed apparatus where hydrodynamic conditions are identical with those found in a packed bed. The experimental results are interpreted in terms of equilibrium and kinetic models to obtain values of characteristic parameters useful in predicting the chromatographic behavior of this stationary phase. Finally, a model is used to predict adsorption/desorption cycles in a column and the predictions are compared with experimental results. Experimental SectionARTICLE SECTIONSJump ToMaterials and Methods. The stationary phase used in this work is S-HyperD-M and was obtained from BioSepra, Inc. (Marlborough, MA). S-HyperD consists of polystyrene-coated high-porosity silica particles whose pores have been filled with a poly(acrylamide) hydrogel that has a strong cation exchange functionality. Basic physical property data and pretreatment conditions are given by Weaver and Carta (1996). The porosity of the silica support matrix is 0.65 (value supplied by the manufacturer), and the density of the hydrated particles was determined to be 1.424 g/cm3. The volume-average particle size of the S-HyperD-M sample used in this work (Lot. 4047) is 78 μm. Chicken egg white lysozyme (crystallized, dialyzed, and lyophilized three times), obtained from Sigma Chemical Co. (St. Louis, MO), was used as a model protein for this study. This protein has a pI of about 11, a partial specific volume of 0.7 cm3/g, and an aqueous diffusivity of 1.1 × 10-6 cm2/s (Mahler and Cordes, 1966). Its dimensions are approximately 4.5 × 3 × 3 nm (Whitley et al., 1989). Other chemicals used in this work were also obtained from Sigma Chemical Co. and Fisher Scientific (Pittsburgh, PA). All experiments were conducted at room temperature (23 ± 2 °C) in a 10 mM Na2HPO4 aqueous buffer adjusted to pH 6.5 with acetic acid. Protein concentrations in solution were determined using a Beckman model DU7 spectrophotometer. Equilibrium Experiments. The static uptake capacity was determined from batch experiments as described by Weaver and Carta (1996). Experiments were done with different NaCl concentrations in the range 0−1000 mM in the 10 mM Na2HPO4 pH 6.5 buffer. Transient Adsorption and Desorption Experiments. The rates of adsorption and desorption were determined both in an agitated vessel and in a shallow-bed contactor. The agitated vessel system is described in Weaver and Carta (1996). Adsorption rates are obtained by rapidly adding a sample of protein-free particles to a volume of lysozyme solution and measuring the decrease in protein concentration as a function of time. Similarly, desorption rates are obtained by adding a sample of lysozyme-loaded particles to a volume of a salt solution and recording the rise in protein concentration as a function of time. A magnetically driven impeller was used to mix the solution and fully suspend the particles at about 300 rpm. Extraparticle mass transfer in such a system depends on the power input per unit mass (Armenante and Kirwan, 1989) which has been estimated as 450 ± 190 cm2/s3 (Weaver and Carta, 1996). Borst et al. (1997) verified this value by measuring the external mass transfer coefficient, kf, for ion-exchange particles suspended in the same vessel for conditions where the external resistance is known to be controlling and comparing the experimental value with the values predicted from available correlations. For these conditions, the kf-value for lysozyme on S-HyperD-M is estimated using the Armenante and Kirwan correlation to be 0.0020 ± 0.0002 cm/s. This value is in fairly good agreement with the experimentally determined value of kf = 0.0026 cm/s obtained by Weaver and Carta (1996). The shallow-bed contactor is similar to one used by Fernandez et al. (1996) and is a modification of the classic shallow bed technique developed by Boyd et al. (1947). The shallow bed is obtained by packing a thin layer of S-HyperD-M (approximately 0.005 cm3 of particle volume) between two layers of Q-HyperD-M particles in a 0.3 cm diameter, 1.2 cm long stainless steel column. Q-HyperD-M (BioSepra, Inc., Marlborough, MA) has essentially the same particle size distribution of S-HyperD-M, but possesses a strong anion exchange functionality (Fernandez and Carta, 1996). Thus, Q-HyperD particles are completely inert with respect to lysozyme at pH 6.5, where this protein has a strong positive charge. The minicolumn is fitted at both ends with Omnifit endcaps (Omni, Toms River, NJ) with 0.5 μm stainless steel frits. The exact volume of S-HyperD-M particles packed was too small to be determined accurately by direct measurement. Thus, it was determined by measuring the lysozyme equilibrium uptake capacity of the shallow bed as described below, and comparing the value to the known equilibrium capacity per unit particle volume obtained from batch equilibrium experiments. The shallow-bed assembly was used with the apparatus shown schematically in Figure 1. It comprises a ProSys Chromatography Workstation (BioSepra, Inc., Marlborough, MA) and an electrically actuated flow-switching valve (Valco Instrument Co., Inc., Houston, TX, model ECSF4E). Three of the pumps (labeled P1, P2, and P3 in Figure 1) in the workstation are set to a desired flow rate and pump continuously either to the column or back to the fluid reservoirs as directed by the flow switching valve. A nearly instantaneous switching of flows to the shallow-bed assembly is obtained by rotating the valve position. The latter is controlled by a programmed output signal from the ProSys unit. For an adsorption experiment, the protein solution is fed to the shallow bed for a desired period of time. The bed is then supplied with the buffer solution to remove protein held in the interparticle space. Finally, the amount of protein adsorbed is determined by passing the buffered 500 mM NaCl solution through the shallow bed and determining the area of the elution peak recorded spectrophotometrically at either 254 or 280 nm. The area is converted to mass of protein using calibration curves which were obtained by feeding protein standards. These calibration curves were found to be linear for lysozyme concentrations up to about 2 mg/cm3. A typical UV and conductivity trace obtained for a protein concentration of 0.1 mg/cm3 with an adsorption time of 240 s and a flow rate of 4 cm3/min is shown in Figure 2. Note that breakthrough of protein occurs nearly instantaneously confirming the differential nature of the shallow-bed assembly. Indeed, the residence time  through the S-HyperD-M layer is estimated to be only about 0.3 s. For a desorption experiment, the shallow bed is loaded to equilibrium with a protein solution containing no NaCl. A buffered salt solution with a desired NaCl concentration is then passed through the bed. The amount of protein desorbed up to a particular time since introduction of the salt solution is determined by calculating the area of the elution peak up to that particular time. All area integrations were performed with the ProSys unit software.  Figure 1 Schematic of shallow-bed apparatus.High Resolution ImageDownload MS PowerPoint Slide Figure 2 Typical UV (solid line) and conductivity (dotted line) traces for a shallow-bed adsorption run. The protein concentration was 0.1 mg/cm3 and the eluent NaCl concentration was 500 mM.High Resolution ImageDownload MS PowerPoint SlideShallow-bed devices of analogous construction have been used by several other authors for liquid-phase adsorption (e.g., Jones and Carta, 1993; Yoshida et al., 1994; Gowanlock et al., 1996). An advantage is that adsorption rates are obtained for hydrodynamic conditions similar to those that could be found in a packed column. In addition, measurements are obtained for a constant solution concentration (equal to the feed concentration) which facilitates interpretation of the results. Column Experiments. Frontal loading and salt-step elution chromatographic experiments were conducted in a 0.3-cm-diameter, 10-cm-long glass column (Omni, Toms River, NJ). The same apparatus used for shallow-bed runs was used for these experiments. The column effluent UV absorbance and conductivity were monitored. During elution, for some conditions, the protein effluent concentration rose above 2 mg/cm3. In this case, effluent fractions were collected with a Gilson model 201 fraction collector and analyzed after dilution. Results and AnalysisARTICLE SECTIONSJump ToUptake Equilibrium. Uptake equilibrium isotherms are shown in Figure 3 at different salt concentrations. Results at 0 and 100 mM NaCl obtained by Weaver and Carta (1996) are included in this figure and are in agreement with new determinations. The uptake equilibrium (which is expressed on a particle volume basis) decreases as a function of salt concentration in the range 0−150 mM, with the isotherms becoming progressively more linear. At salt concentrations of 300 mM or greater, no uptake of lysozyme was detectable.  Figure 3 Equilibrium uptake isotherms for lysozyme on S-HyperD-M at different NaCl concentrations. The graph includes data by Weaver and Carta (1996) indicated by filled symbols. Lines are based on eq 1 with parameters from Table 1.High Resolution ImageDownload MS PowerPoint SlidePartitioning of charged proteins in charged gels is dependent simultaneously on steric hindrance effects and electrostatic interactions. Some recent theoretical advances have been made in the description of these  systems (Sassi et al., 1996; Johnson and Deen, 1996). However, these theories are generally limited to dilute systems with low charge density. Thus, an empirical approach was deemed necessary here. As shown by several authors (e.g., Tsou and Graham, 1985; Skidmore et al., 1990; Yoshida et al., 1994), the Langmuir isotherm with salt-dependent coefficients often provides an adequate description of protein ion-exchange equilibria: This works well for our system also, when both qm and b are allowed to vary with salt concentration. The parameters qm and b were determined from a nonlinear least-squares fit of the data and their values are given in Table 1. Figure 3 shows the isotherms calculated using these values.  Figure 4 Batch uptake kinetics for lysozyme on S-HyperD-M at different NaCl concentrations. Lines are based on the homogeneous diffusion model with Ds = 7.5 × 10-9 cm2 and kf = 0.0026 cm/s with equilibrium parameters from Table 1. V = 100 cm3, VM = 0.25 cm3, and C0 = 1 mg/cm3.High Resolution ImageDownload MS PowerPoint Slide Table 1. Adsorption Equilibrium Parameters for Lysozyme on S-HyperD-M at pH 6.5[NaCl] (mM)qmbb (cm3/mg) 0 30100 115 75 2030 9.39 100 823 3.77 150 199 0.701Batch and Shallow-Bed Adsorption Kinetics. The effect of salt concentration on the concentration history during adsorption of lysozyme in the stirred batch apparatus is shown in Figure 4. The initial protein concentration in solution was 1 mg/cm3, and the volume of particles was 0.25 ± 0.01 cm3. Since the equilibrium uptake becomes less favorable as the salt concentration is increased, the curves approach higher asymptotic values going from 0 to 150 mM NaCl. As shown by Weaver and Carta (1996), at 0 mM NaCl, the batch uptake process is described by the following equations that take into account intraparticle and external mass transfer resistances: These equations assume that intraparticle mass transfer occurs via homogeneous diffusion with a driving force expressed as the gradient in the adsorbed solute concentration. Ci is the interfacial protein concentration and is obtained from eq 1. For the case where no NaCl was added, Weaver and Carta (1996) have obtained Ds = 7.5 × 10-9 cm2/s and kf = 0.0026 cm/s. These values were shown to yield consistent predictions when the protein concentration was varied between 0.1 and 2 mg/cm3. Thus, the same values were used to predict the uptake curves shown in Figure 4 at different salt concentrations. For this purpose, eqs 2 and 3 were solved numerically (see Weaver and Carta, 1996) using the equilibrium parameter values summarized in Table 1. As seen in Figure 4, the agreement between experimental results and predicted curves is excellent, especially considering that the initial slope of the isotherm changes by a factor of about 150 when the salt concentration is increased from 0 to 150 mM. It is also of interest to compare these batch uptake curves with the behavior that would be predicted by a pore diffusion model, where the driving force is expressed in terms of a gradient in free protein concentration. The latter, of course, could not exceed the external solution concentration. The relevant equations are given in Weaver and Carta (1996) and express the rate of mass transfer in terms of an effective pore diffusivity, De = εpD/τ. Curves calculated on the basis of this model are given in Figure 5 in comparison with the experimental results. In each case, the effective diffusivity was adjusted to provide an approximate fit of the experimental curves. Obviously, it is not possible to obtain a good fit of all the data with a single, salt-independent effective diffusivity; in fact, the value of De needed to fit the data decreases as the curvature of the adsorption isotherm decreases. What is even more important is that the effective diffusivity values needed to fit the data at the lower salt concentrations are higher than the free solution diffusivity. Using the aqueous diffusivity of lysozyme of 1.1 × 10-6 cm2/s, a porosity of 0.65 equal to that of the rigid support matrix, and a tortuosity value of 2 as is typical, gives a De value of about 3.6 × 10-7 cm2/s, nearly an order of magnitude smaller than the value of De = 2.8 × 10-6 cm2/s needed to fit the 0 mM NaCl data. The fact that the apparent De values are larger than the estimated effective pore diffusivity is likely a result of the large driving force deriving from the favorable partitioning of protein into the gel-filling of these particles. As the salt concentration is increased, partitioning becomes less favorable, and the apparent effective pore diffusivity decreases.  Figure 5 Batch uptake kinetics for lysozyme on S-HyperD-M at different NaCl concentrations. Lines are based on the pore diffusion model with kf = 0.0026 cm/s and fitted values of the apparent effective pore diffusivity De with equilibrium parameters from Table 1. Data are the same as in Figure 4.High Resolution ImageDownload MS PowerPoint SlideIt should be noted that in the interpretation of the results, a single concentration-independent effective diffusivity value Ds is used. This value should be regarded as an average over the particle radius since  variations could be expected as a function of protein loading, as a result of coupling of ion fluxes, and as a result of possible local heterogeneity in the physical structure of the particles and in the distribution of ionogenic functional groups. A final note also concerns the effect of particle size. This effect was not specifically investigated in this work. However, it was examined for gel-composite particles of similar structure but with an anion-exchange functionality (Q-HyperD) by Fernandez and Carta (1996) and Fernandez et al. (1996). Results obtained with particles approximately 50 and 80 μm in diameter showed that the uptake rate varies inversely with the square of the particle size in agreement with Fick's law. A similar result is expected for the particles studied in this work. Two questions remain to be answered:  (a) Does the use of the particles in a packed bed operated at high velocities of the mobile phase affect the rate of intraparticle mass transfer of lysozyme in S-HyperD? (b) Is the rate of desorption of lysozyme from these particles predicted by the same model? To answer the first question, we conducted adsorption experiments in the shallow-bed apparatus. The results are shown in Figure 6 for lysozyme concentrations of 1 and 0.1 mg/cm3 with a superficial velocity of 3400 cm/h. Calculated curves based on the homogeneous diffusion model (with C = CF constant in eq 2c) with Ds = 7.5 × 10-9 cm2/s and kf = 0.0029 cm/s are also shown in this figure. The diffusivity value is the same obtained from batch experiments. The kf value, however, was obtained by matching the initial slope of the data at 0.1 mg/cm3 protein concentration, to the limiting solution of the model equations with C = CF for the case where the external resistance is controlling: This solution is valid, for short times, when the dimensionless group δ = kf rpCF/5qFDs is less than one (Fernandez et al., 1996). For a highly favorable isotherm, as is observed here when no salt is added to the pH 6.5 buffer, this dimensionless group is equivalent to the so-called Helfferich number and is a measure of the relative rates of external mass transfer and intraparticle diffusion (Helfferich and Hwang, 1991). For the 0.1 mg/cm3 run in Figure 6, δ ∼ 0.12. Thus, the external resistance is indeed controlling for these conditions. Conversely, at 1 mg/cm3, δ becomes larger than unity, so that intraparticle mass transfer becomes dominant except at very short times. The close agreement between shallow-bed results and predictions made with Ds = 7.5 × 10-9 cm2/s indicates that intraparticle mass transfer rates are unaffected by operation in a packed bed as, apparently, the rigid matrix prevents mechanical compression of the polyacrylamide gel contained within the particles.  Figure 6 Shallow-bed uptake kinetics for lysozyme on S-HyperD-M at different protein concentrations. Lines are based on the homogeneous diffusion model with Ds = 7.5 × 10-9 cm2 and kf = 0.0029 cm/s with equilibrium parameters from Table 1. [NaCl] = 0 mM.High Resolution ImageDownload MS PowerPoint SlideDesorption Kinetics. To determine the rate of protein desorption in response to a step in salt concentration, desorption experiments were conducted both in the agitated vessel and in the shallow bed apparatus. The results are shown in parts a and b of Figure 7. In both cases, the S-HyperD particles were presaturated with 1 mg/cm3 lysozyme in pH 6.5 buffer, yielding an initial protein loading of about 250 mg/cm3 (see Figure 3). The particles were then exposed to buffered solutions containing different NaCl concentrations. Several interesting trends can be noted. First, it is apparent that the adsorption of lysozyme is reversible over the range of salt concentrations shown in parts a and b of Figure 7. In fact, in the shallow-bed contactor, even at 100 mM salt, the protein will eventually become completely desorbed from the particles. Second, it is clear that the desorption behavior is independent of the NaCl concentration for concentrations of 300 mM or greater. For these conditions there is no tendency to bind lysozyme, and the rate of mass transfer is completely controlled by intraparticle transport. This apparently occurs at the same rate in the range 300−1000 mM NaCl. At lower salt concentrations, however, when lysozyme is favorably partitioned in the stationary phase, the desorption behavior is affected by the shape of the isotherm. At 150 mM salt, for example, the time required to attain nearly complete desorption increases from about 200 s to about 1000 s. When the salt concentration is lowered to 100 mM this time exceeds 8000 s as these conditions still strongly favor binding of the protein (see Figure 3). Finally, we can directly compare the 500 and 1000 mM data in Figure 7a with those in Figure 7b since, for these conditions, the protein is completely desorbed even in the batch contactor. Essentially identical curves are obtained in the two contactors. Thus, it is apparent that the desorption  behavior is virtually independent of hydrodynamic conditions outside the particle. This indicates that S-HyperD retains its structural integrity and intraparticle diffusional characteristics at elevated flow rates of the mobile phase even during desorption at high salt concentrations.  Figure 7 Desorption kinetics for lysozyme adsorbed on S-HyperD at different salt concentrations. The particles were initially equilibrated with 1 mg/cm3 lysozyme in pH 6.5 buffer. Key:  (a) batch kinetics; (b) shallow-bed kinetics. Lines are based on the homogeneous diffusion model with kf = 0.0026 cm/s for the batch runs and kf = 0.0029 cm/s for the shallow bed runs.High Resolution ImageDownload MS PowerPoint SlideTo compare adsorption and desorption rates, we used the homogeneous diffusion model, eqs 2 and 3 for the batch runs or eq 2 alone with C = CF = 0 for the shallow-bed runs, to predict the desorption behavior. Calculated curves for Ds = 7.5 × 10-9 cm2/s using the isotherm parameters in Table 1 are shown by the solid lines in parts a and b of Figure 7. At 100 and 150 mM salt concentrations, it appears that only relatively minor differences exist between experimental and predicted curves, indicating that, for these low-salt conditions, mass transfer mechanisms are similar for both adsorption and desorption. The relatively small differences observed between experimental and predicted behavior could be attributed, at least in part, to inaccuracies in the determination and fitting of the isotherms. In addition, differences could also arise because the diffusivity is likely to vary to some extent with protein loading. At salt concentrations of 300 mM or higher, however, a different behavior is observed. In this case, the desorption rate is seen to be substantially higher than predicted. In fact, while the same model could be used to fit the experimental data, a substantially higher diffusivity value of 20 × 10-9 cm2/s was needed. Predicted curves based on this value are shown by the dashed lines in parts a and b of Figure 7. It is apparent that this Ds value provides a good fit of all data at high salt concentrations both in the batch and in the shallow-bed contactor. For these high salt conditions, of course, there is no tendency to bind lysozyme, so that it is reasonable to expect that less diffusional hindrance will occur as compared to the cases where protein binding is significant. Comparison of Experimental and Estimated Diffusivity. It is of interest to compare these diffusivity values with available theories for transport of macromolecules in fibrous gels. No theory is currently available for transport of a cationic macromolecule in an anionic gel. However, theories for neutral species are available, such as the effective-medium model used by Howells (1974) and Phillips et al. (1989, 1990). According to this model, the ratio of diffusivities in a gel and in solution is given by where rm is the radius of the diffusing molecule and k is the hydraulic Darcy permeability. This equation has had some success in predicting the diffusion behavior in free gels (Phillips et al., 1989, Tong and Anderson, 1996). For spherical solutes, rm can be estimated from the Stokes−Einstein radius (rm = 1.98 nm for lysozyme). The Darcy permeability, k, can be calculated for well-defined geometries (Howells, 1974; Phillips et al., 1989) or measured experimentally for more complex systems. Kapur et al. (1996) have recently measured the hydrodynamic permeability of charged poly(acrylamide) gels (S and Q) supported in rigid porous membranes. The gels used by these authors are equivalent to those used in preparing HyperD and the membranes used to support the gel have pore size and porosity similar to the silica matrix of the HyperD particles. For the S-gel, Kapur et al. found that k has little sensitivity to salt concentration and gave values of (0.15 ± 0.02) × 10-14 cm2 for a range of ionic strengths between 10 and 1000 mM. Using this value in eq 5 yields Dg ∼ 7.4 × 10-8 cm2/s for lysozyme. To compare this value with the Ds values reported in this work, it is necessary to make allowances for the porosity and tortuosity factor of the rigid support matrix of S-HyperD. Using values of 0.65 and 2 for these parameters as before, an effective diffusivity of 0.65 × 7.4 × 10-8/2 = 24 × 10-9 cm2/s can be estimated for transport in S-HyperD of a neutral molecule of the same size of lysozyme. This value is close to the effective diffusivity Ds obtained experimentally at high salt concentrations, where the electrostatic interaction between lysozyme and the gel's functional groups is presumably suppressed. A lower value of the effective diffusivity was, however, obtained at low salt concentrations, for conditions were the protein is very favorably partitioned. In fact, even at 150 mM salt concentrations, the partition coefficient at 1 mg/cm3 protein concentration exceeds 100. For these conditions, essentially all of the protein contained in the particles is in a bound form. The electrostatic interaction responsible for solute binding apparently increases diffusional hindrance within the gel. Prediction of Breakthrough and Elution Behavior. The results of four successive experimental runs conducted at a mobile phase superficial velocity of 3400 cm/h with a 10 cm-long column are shown in Figure 8a−d. Each experiment involved loading the column with 1 mg/cm3 lysozyme in pH 6.5 buffer for 2400 s, followed by a wash step for 1260 s where only buffer was supplied to the column, and by an elution step, where a buffered salt solution was fed. Four different salt concentrations (100, 150, 500, and 1000 mM) were used in the elution step. As the salt concentration is increased, a sharper elution peak is obtained since equilibrium becomes less and less favorable. However, there is no significant difference between the elution peaks at 500 and 1000 mM salt since equilibrium limitations are completely removed at these concentrations. Loading was with 1 mg/cm3 lysozyme in pH 6.5 buffer; wash was with pH 6.5 buffer; elution was with (a) 100 mM NaCl, (b) 150 mM NaCl, (c) 500 mM NaCl, and (d) 1000 mM NaCl.High Resolution ImageDownload MS PowerPoint Slide Figure 9 Salt breakthrough profile for the 10 cm-long S-HyperD-M column at 3400 cm/h. Experimental results are shown for the clean column and the column preequilibrated with 1 mg/cm3 lysozyme in pH 6.5 buffer. The latter traces correspond to the experiments in parts a and c Figure7. The salt step is applied at t = 3660 s.High Resolution ImageDownload MS PowerPoint SlideNeglecting axial dispersion, protein loading and wash steps are described by the following equations representing solute balances for the column and adsorbent particles where ε is the void fraction and u is the superficial velocity. Equations 6 and 7, coupled with the particle conservation equation, eq 2, and with the equilibrium isotherm, eq 1, were solved numerically by orthogonal collocation using a method similar to that of Saunders et al. (1989). It should be noted that while simpler constant-pattern solutions can be used for the protein loading step (Weaver and Carta, 1996; Fernandez et al., 1996), a numerical solution is required for the wash and  elution steps since equilibrium is favorable. A value of ε = 0.47, determined by matching the total column capacity to the equilibrium capacity, was used for these calculations. This value is in agreement with previous direct determinations of the void fraction of HyperD columns (Fernandez et al., 1996). The results are shown by the solid curves in Figure 8a−d. There is an excellent agreement between experimental breakthrough and predicted curves. Some discrepancies are observed in the wash step, where leakage of protein from the column is overestimated by the model. This discrepancy is likely a result of inaccuracies in the determination of the adsorption isotherm at very low protein concentrations. As shown in Figure 3, the isotherm at 0 mM salt is extremely steep. Thus, the desorption curve during the wash step is extremely sensitive to even small changes in the slope of the isotherm at these low concentrations. To predict the elution behavior, it is necessary to understand how the salt propagates through the column. In principle, an exact model would require a description of salt−protein interactions. In practice, however, we found that this is not strictly necessary. Figure 9 shows the salt breakthrough profiles (obtained from conductivity measurements) for elutions with 100 and 500 mM salt for two extreme cases; in the first, the column was free of protein, and in the second, the column was saturated with protein prior to the salt step. The runs in the second case correspond to the experiments in parts a and c of Figure 8. It is apparent that movement of salt through the column occurs very rapidly and, over this range, is virtually independent of salt concentration and of whether the packing is saturated with protein or not. This occurs principally because the salt is in large equivalent excess over the adsorbed protein. As a result, for a practical prediction of the elution behavior it is sufficient to assume that the entire column is instantaneously exposed to the salt concentration in the eluent. Equations 6 and 7 coupled with eqs 1 and 2 can thus be used with the appropriate initial conditions. Numerically calculated curves based on these equations and the independently determined equilibrium parameters are shown in Figure 8a−d. Values of Ds = 7.5 × 10-9 and 20 × 10-9 cm2/s were used for the 100 and 150 mM and for the 500 and 1000 mM elutions, respectively, in accordance with the batch and shallow-bed determinations. An excellent agreement is obtained in all cases, demonstrating that the model developed captures the essential traits of equilibrium and transport processes in these particles. Obviously, since there is no equilibrium uptake of protein and the same diffusivity value is used, curves predicted at 500 and 1000 mM salt concentrations, are identical as is observed experimentally. In this case, essentially complete recovery of the protein is obtained in about 540 s. Much longer times are required at 150 mM. At 100 mM salt concentration, even after 3600 s from the beginning of the salt step, recovery of the protein initially adsorbed is only about 72%. The elution profile, in this case, extends to very long times. However, we observed that any residual protein could be quickly eluted by switching the eluent to one containing a higher salt concentration. SummaryARTICLE SECTIONSJump ToIntraparticle mass transfer of lysozyme in the gel-composite S-HyperD particles is consistent with a diffusion model where the driving force is the gradient in total protein concentration within the particle. At low protein concentrations and when equilibrium partitioning is favorable, the external resistance to mass transfer becomes dominant. For salt concentrations in the range 0−150 mM, a single effective diffusivity Ds = 7.5 × 10-9 cm2/s adequately describes intraparticle transport for both adsorption and desorption conditions. Thus, over this range, differences in the mass transfer rates observed with different salt concentrations can be ascribed entirely to differences in the equilibrium isotherms. At higher salt concentrations, when there is no tendency to bind lysozyme, a higher Ds value is needed to describe the experimental behavior with this model. This increase could reflect an increased mobility of the protein molecules within the gel in the absence of binding. This higher Ds value, however, remains independent of salt in the range 300−1000 mM. Estimates of intraparticle diffusivities based on experimental values of the gel Darcy permeability of Kapur et al. (1996) appear to support the physical significance of these effective diffusivity determinations. The unique structure of this gel-composite medium results in a large protein uptake capacity and a rapid mass transfer kinetics. As a consequence of the mechanical strength of the support matrix, these desirable properties are preserved when the particles are used in a packed bed operated at an extremely high flow rate of the mobile phase. A model based on the independently determined equilibrium and rate parameters is shown to provide an excellent prediction of loading/wash/elution cycles for lysozyme in a chromatographic column packed with S-HyperD. Such a model could be used for an optimization of step times in a protein recovery process. Patterns of protein adsorption in chromatographic particles visualized by optical microscopy - ScienceDirect

ScienceDirectJournals & BooksHelpSearchInstitutionRegisterSign in PDFView PDFDownload Full IssueSearchJournal of Chromatography AVolume 1160, Issues 1–2, 10 August 2007, Pages 206-214Patterns of protein adsorption in chromatographic particles visualized by optical microscopyAuthor links open overlay panelMelani C.StoneGiorgioCartaPersonEnvelopeShow moreNavigate DownPlusAdd to MendeleyShareShareCited ByCitehttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.chroma.2007.05.058Get rights and contentAbstractA new method is presented to image transient patterns of protein adsorption in individual spherical chromatographic particles under strong binding conditions. The method takes advantage of the difference in refractive index between the protein-free and protein-saturated adsorbent matrix. When the particles are viewed with an ordinary microscope using white light illumination, the adsorption front appears as a bright ring that moves in time from the surface of the particle to its center. Experimental data are obtained for the proteins lysozyme and albumin with a commercial agarose-based cation exchanger. Sharp rings are observed in both cases confirming that protein mass transfer within the particles occurs via a shell-progressive diffusion mechanism. Quantitative analysis based on the shrinking core model provides an accurate and precise way of determining the intraparticle diffusivity for individual particles as a function of protein concentration and mobile phase composition.Navigate LeftPrevious article in issueNext article in issueNavigate RightKeywordsAdsorptionDiffusionVisualizationProteinsChromatographyRecommended articlesCited by (0)View AbstractCopyright © 2007 Elsevier B.V. ScienceDirectJournals & BooksHelpSearchInstitutionRegisterSign in PDFView PDFDownload Full IssueSearchJournal of Chromatography AVolume 1356, 22 August 2014, Pages 129-137Unfolding and aggregation of a glycosylated monoclonal antibody on a cation exchange column. Part II. Protein structure effects by hydrogen deuterium exchange mass spectrometryAuthor links open overlay panelJingGuoGiorgioCartaPersonEnvelopeShow moreNavigate DownPlusAdd to MendeleyShareShareCited ByCitehttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.chroma.2014.06.038Get rights and contentHighlights•HX-MS reveals the nature of a mAb eluting as two peaks from a CEX resin.•HX-MS shows that that the CEX resin causes formation of an unfolded intermediate.•HX-MS shows that eluted aggregates and unfolded intermediate are related.•The mechanism for the mAb two-peak elution and aggregation is established.AbstractHydrogen-deuterium exchange mass spectrometry (HX-MS) with proteolytic fragmentation is used to determine patterns of unfolding, as measured by increased solvent exposure, with peptide-level resolution for a glycosylated monoclonal antibody both when eluted from a tentacle-type cation exchange column (Fractogel EMD SO3-) and while bound to the resin. Two peaks are obtained when the bound protein is eluted with either a NaCl gradient or with two NaCl steps at increasing concentration. The first, early eluting peak contains only monomeric species whose structure is consistent with the native monomer. The second, late eluting peak contains a mixture of monomeric and aggregated species. The monomeric species in this mixture is also found to have a structure consistent with that of the native mAb, showing no evidence of increased solvent exposure. The aggregated species show instead significant unfolding in areas of the protein structure contained within the Fc region. The same peptides that exhibit the greatest level of solvent exposure in the aggregated species are also found in the fraction of protein that elutes from the resin only at high salt concentration, indicating that the aggregates are formed when the strongly-bound unfolded intermediate is desorbed at high salt. There is no evidence that the unfolded intermediate, formed while the protein is bound on the resin, is present in any of the eluted fractions indicating that, upon desorption from the resin, the intermediate either quickly refolds or forms aggregates which end-up co-eluting with the refolded protein at high salt concentrations.Navigate LeftPrevious article in issueNext article in issueNavigate RightKeywordsMonoclonal antibodyCation exchangeUnfoldingAggregationHydrogen-deuterium exchange mass spectrometryRecommended articlesCited by (0)View AbstractCopyright © 2014 Elsevier B.V. Get e-AlertsAbstractA simulated moving bed adsorptive reactor (SMBR) has been developed and tested experimentally to conduct a regioselective enzyme-catalyzed diol esterification in a hexane solvent. The reaction is equilibrium limited, and accumulation of water on the biocatalyst causes a reduction in biocatalytic activity. As a result simultaneous removal of water by adsorption on a catalytically inert ion-exchange resin in Na form has been used to improve conversion. A three-zone SMBR system was developed for this purpose integrating reaction, adsorption, and regeneration. The packed beds in the three zones are periodically advanced in a “merry-go-round” fashion to simulate countercurrent flow. The SMBR allows continuous operation while reducing desorbent consumption and improving conversion relative to a conventional fixed-bed reactor. A mathematical model was developed to simulate the SMBR system based on independent analyses of adsorption and reaction phenomena. The model takes into account the interplay of these phenomena and provides a useful tool to understand the effects of process variables and for the selection of optimum operating conditions. *  Corresponding author. Telephone:  (434) 924 6281. FAX:  (434) 982 2658. E-mail:  gc@virginia.edu.IntroductionARTICLE SECTIONSJump ToThe discovery that certain enzymes, such as lipases, can also function in nearly anhydrous organic solvents 1 has greatly expanded the range of substrates usable in biocatalytic reactions, spurring a growing interest in new industrial applications. Much of the industrial interest stems from the chemospecificity, regioselectivity, and stereoselectivity that is often exhibited by these biocatalysts. 2-6 Moreover, enzymes are thought to be more environmentally friendly than many conventional catalysts and work at moderate temperatures and pH. Esterifications are among the most industrially interesting reactions in this area. 7 However, while, these reactions are of great interest for the synthesis of flavors and fragrances, pharmaceutical intermediates, and specialty chemicals, they are often subject to thermodynamic equilibrium limitations 8-10 as well as to loss of catalytic activity when water produced in the reaction accumulates on the biocatalyst. 11 Thus, in general, the water produced in these reactions must be controlled in order to attain high conversions and preserve the biocatalyst activity. It has been suggested 12,13 that water can be controlled by limiting its thermodynamic activity in the reaction mixture, because that in turn controls the reaction equilibrium and the partitioning of substrates and products between the reaction mixture and the biocatalyst. Several approaches have been proposed to achieve this, including the use of salt hydrates 14 pervaporation through water-selective membranes, 15,16 free and vacuum evaporation, 17 distillation, 18 and air sparging. 19 Adsorption onto a water-selective medium has also been considered by a number of authors 17,20 and is of particular interest because of the ease with which adsorbents can be incorporated into packed bed reactors that are often preferred for enzymatic conversions. 21,22 For example, Mensah et al. 11,23 and Migliorini et al. 24 have shown that catalytically inert ion-exchange resins are effective for in situ control of water in enzymatic reactions, with the advantage that removal of the adsorbed water can be done with a polar solvent, without having to separate the biocatalyst from the adsorbent. However, to obtain a continuous operation of adsorptive reactor, systems that integrate reaction, separation, and regeneration steps efficiently are desirable. Simulated moving bed reactor (SMBR) systems have been developed for this purpose. SMBR systems simulate a countercurrent flow of the adsorbent/catalyst and the fluid phase through the use of multiple fixed beds advanced in a “merry-go-round” fashion. The technology draws upon the success of simulated moving bed separators that are now used extensively on a large scale 25 but incorporates a reactive component. As such, they retain the advantages of true countercurrent reactor systems without the operational complexities of actually moving adsorbent/catalyst particles. A number of laboratory studies of SMBR systems have appeared in the literature in recent years, including reactors for the hydrogenation of mesitylene, 26-29 for the oxidative coupling of methane, 30-32 and for a number of sulfonic acid resin catalyzed esterifications, transesterifications, and acetylations. 33-35 Some experimental applications to enzyme-catalyzed reactions have also been studied such as the enzymatic isomerization of glucose to fructose 36 and lipase-catalyzed transesterifications, 37 and a number of theoretical studies of adsorptive reactors have been conducted. 38-41 However, despite these studies, no industrial scale applications of adsorptive SMBR have been reported. It is hoped that a better understanding of the interplay of adsorptive and reaction phenomena and the exploration of the potential for applications in critical fields such as biocatalysis will allow practical implementation of these reactors. It should be noted that biocatalytic reactions are good candidates because the temperature is low so that adsorption can be effective. The objective of this work is to determine the suitability of an SMBR system for a reversible regioselective enzymatic esterification. The reaction considered is the lipase-catalyzed esterification of propionic acid and 2-ethyl-1,3-hexanediol to form the primary monoester and water according to The reaction occurs in a nearly anhydrous hexane solvent and is equilibrium limited (K = 0.6 at 22 °C).24 The biocatalyst is Lipozyme IM (Novo Nordisk Bioindustrials, Inc., Franklinton, NC) and consists of a Mucor miehei lipase immobilized on a macroporous polymeric support. Direct conversions of diols to their monoester are of considerable importance as these products have applications in cosmetics, pharmaceutical intermediates, and surfactants.2 Biocatalytic routes are often desirable for these applications because of regulatory and selectivity considerations. High Resolution ImageDownload MS PowerPoint SlideThe Lipozyme biocatalyst used in this work is highly selective for the primary monoester and exhibits long-term stability. However, as shown by Migliorini et al.,24 accumulation of water on the biocatalyst reduces its catalytic activity. Thus, adsorption of water onto the biocatalyst must be prevented to maintain the highest reaction rates. Migliorini at al. studied the adsorption-assisted operation of this reaction by incorporating an ion-exchange resin as a water adsorbent together with the biocatalyst in batch and fixed-bed reactors. In situ water removal was shown to provide two distinct advantages:  it shifted the thermodynamic equilibrium toward high conversion and it prevented accumulation of water on the biocatalyst, maintaining high activity. Since these advantages are realized only during transient operation of these reactors, the application of an SMBR system integrating reaction, adsorption, and regeneration is developed in this work. SMBR SystemARTICLE SECTIONSJump ToThe SMBR considered in this work is shown schematically in Figure 1. It consists of three separate zones with intermediate feed and product withdrawal points. The acid substrate feed is supplied continuously to zone III, while the diol substrate feed is supplied continuously to zone I. A “raffinate” stream containing the ester product is recovered from zone III, while an “extract” stream containing the water product and excess diol fed to the system is withdrawn from zone I. Each zone comprises multiple beds, and the inner arrow shows the direction of bed switching. In practice, of course, this motion is obtained by the periodic switching of valves. The switching time, p, is related to the equivalent solid and liquid velocities in a true countercurrent system by the following equations: where ε is the bed void fraction, L is the bed length, and ui is the fluid-phase velocity. The latter is different in each zone as a result of the addition or withdrawal of streams.  Figure 1 Simulated moving bed reactor concept.High Resolution ImageDownload MS PowerPoint SlideThe role played by the different zones in the SMBR is as follows. Zone III serves as the reaction/separation zone. In this zone the acid substrate reacts with the diol entering from zone II to form the ester and water. The water produced is adsorbed and is carried upstream by the solid phase with each successive switch. The bulk of the adsorbed water is removed in zone I by the diol substrate, which is fed in amounts in excess of the stoichiometric reaction requirement. The regenerated adsorbent is thus returned to zone III. The excess diol and desorbed water are purged from the system in the extract stream, which is withdrawn between zones I and II. A portion of the diol stream emerging from zone I enters zone II. The function of this zone is to remove water from the diol, preventing a high water concentration from entering the reaction/separation zone (zone III) and preventing the acid and ester produced near the entrance of zone III from being lost in the extract. Figure 1 shows two beds in each zone. While more beds could be added, it has been shown that most of the benefits of the true countercurrent operation can be gained even with only a single bed in each zone. The correct operation of the SMBR requires the selection of fluid velocities in such a way that the adsorbed species (e.g., water) move in the appropriate direction in each zone. Thus, the fluid velocity in the reaction/adsorption zone must be such as to prevent the water produced in the reaction from breaking through in the raffinate. Conversely, the diol feed flow rate must be sufficiently high so that water will be desorbed in zone I and move toward the extract withdrawal point. Finally, the fluid velocity in zone II must be sufficiently low that water is transported by the solid phase toward the extract withdrawal point. Experimental SectionARTICLE SECTIONSJump ToMaterials and Methods. Lipozyme IM was obtained from Novo Nordisk Bioindustrials, Inc., (Franklinton, NC). The biocatalyst has a particle size of 0.04 ± 0.02 cm and a porosity of 0.53 ± 0.02. The initial water content of the fresh Lipozyme IM used in this work was 2.4 ± 0.4 mmol/g, determined through weight loss on drying in an oven at 120 °C. The adsorbent used in this work is Dowex HCR−W2 in Na+ form (Dow Chemical Company, Midland, MI). This is a sulfonated, gel-type polystyrene−divinylbenzene resin with a nominal degree of cross-linking of 8%. The resin consists of spherical particles 0.04 ± 0.02 cm in size. It was converted to the sodium form with 1 N  sodium hydroxide, rinsed with deionized distilled water, and dried in an oven at 120 °C. Propionic acid (99% purity), 2-ethyl-1,3-hexanediol (97% purity), and hexane (capillary GC grade) were obtained from Sigma Chemical Co. (St. Louis, MO). The feed solutions were kept nearly anhydrous by storing them under the Dowex adsorbent material. A 80/100 mesh Chromosorb 101 column (Alltech, Deerfield, IL) was used with a Hewlett-Packard model 5890A gas chromatograph (thermal conductivity detection) for analysis. SMBR Apparatus. A schematic of the SMBR apparatus is shown in Figure 2. For simplicity the diagram shows only three beds (one per zone), although the apparatus could accommodate as many as ten beds. Glass chromatographic columns 1.5 cm in diameter (Omnifit, Toms River, NJ) were used, each containing 2 g of Dowex resin and 4 g of the Lipozyme biocatalyst. The two materials were intimately mixed and poured in the columns. The settled bed height was 7.1 ± 0.1 cm. The total void fraction of these columns was estimated to be 0.66, based on εb = 0.4 and the porosity of Lipozyme. Metering pumps with accuracy of ±0.01 cm3/min (Eldex A-60-S and Eldex B-100-S, Napa, CA) were used to feed the acid and diol streams dissolved in hexane and withdraw the extract stream. The flow rate of the remaining stream (the raffinate) is determined by a mass balance. The desired stream routing is accomplished using rotary stream selector valves (model C25Z-3180E, Valco Instrument Company, Inc., Houston, TX). Check valves (model CV 3000, Upchurch Scientific, Oak Harbor, WA) are placed between each column to prevent backflow. Connections between the columns and valves were made with 1/16 in. PTFE tubing. Samples were collected from the raffinate and extract streams at predetermined time intervals. To prevent evaporation of these samples, a Gilson model 231 autoinjector was modified to automatically collect the raffinate samples and inject them into septum-capped glass vials.  Figure 2 Simulated moving bed reactor apparatus.  High Resolution ImageDownload MS PowerPoint SlideSynchronized switching of the valves was accomplished using electric actuators (model E10, Valco Instrument Company, Inc., Houston, TX) interfaced to a PC-based control system. All experiments were conducted at room temperature 22 ± 2 °C. A summary of operating conditions for the different SMBR runs is given in Table 1. In each case, the desorbent fed to zone I was 3 mol/L diol in hexane. A high diol concentration is desirable because it lowers the thermodynamic activity of water that, in turn, is more efficient for desorption. However, since the diol is rather viscous (μ = 2.8 cp for 3 mol/L diol in hexane at 25 °C), this concentration was used as a compromise. Varied numbers of beds per zone, flow rates, and switch times were used in the different runs.  Table 1.  Experimental Conditions for SMBR Runsarunconfiguration (NI − NII − NIII)QD (cm3/min)QE (cm3/min)QA (cm3/min)p (min) A 1−1−1 0.77 0.68 0.11 180 B 1−1−2 0.77 0.68 0.11 180 C 1−1−3 0.78 0.69 0.11 180 D 1−1−3 0.58 0.51 0.11 240 E 2−1−2 0.40 0.31 0.11 180a CAF = 1.0 mol/L, CDF = 3.0 mol/L, L = 7.1 cm.Mathematical ModelARTICLE SECTIONSJump ToAs discussed above, the correct operation of an SMBR system requires the selection of appropriate fluid-phase velocities in the different zones. For certain idealized conditions (e.g., linear isotherms or Langmuir isotherms) and in the absence of mass transfer and kinetic effects, these operating conditions can be selected on the basis of explicit expressions (see Lode et al.).41 In our case, however, reaction kinetic effects and mass transfer resistances are substantial. Moreover, the adsorption equilibria are dependent on the thermodynamic activity coefficients, which, in turn, vary dramatically as a function the composition of the reactions mixture and, thus, with conversion. A detailed mathematical model was thus developed based on independently determined rate expressions. The equations used to simulate the SMBR system are summarized in Table 2 and are based on the fixed-bed model developed by Migliorini et al.24 Each bed is assumed to be uniformly packed with a homogeneous mixture of the biocatalyst (bed density ρc = 0.32 g/cm3) and the adsorbent (bed density ρa = 0.16 g/cm3). The model comprises (a) the conservation equations (eq 2.1) for each fixed bed assuming axially dispersed plug flow; (b) boundary conditions and mass balances to describe the addition and removal of the fluid streams (eqs 2.2a−f); (c) rate equations based on the LDF approximation (eqs 2.3a−b) to describe the rates of mass transfer between the fluid phase and the biocatalyst and between the fluid phase and the adsorbent; (d) the rate equation for the reaction (eqs 2.4a−b); and (d) adsorption isotherms describing the equilibrium distribution of substrates and products between the fluid phase and the adsorbent and between the fluid phase and the biocatalyst (eqs 2.5a−c). The effects of intercolumn dead volumes were found to be negligible in our experimental system. Thus, this volume was neglected in the mass balances and boundary conditions connecting adjacent columns.  Table 2.  SMBR Model EquationsaBed conservation equations Boundary conditions and mass balances Adsorption rate equations Reaction kinetic model Adsorption equilibria a Subscripts:  A = acid, D = diol, E = ester, W = water, j = 1,2,.....N with N = NI + NII + NIII. Superscripts:  c = catalyst, a = adsorbent, F = feed value, 0 = bed inlet, L = end of bed, * = equilibrium value.The reaction kinetics is described by the reversible Ping Pong Bi−Bi rate expression including substrate inhibition (eq 2.4a) according to the results of Migliorini et al.24 Since the amount of adsorbed water on Lipozyme IM has a strong effect on the biocatalyst activity but no effect on the substrate concentration dependence of the rate,11 the maximum rate parameter rm in the rate  expression is a strong function of the water content of the biocatalyst, qWc. This relationship is expressed by an empirical function (eq 2.4.b). Accordingly, the reaction rate is maximum when qWc→0, it remains nearly constant up to qWc∼3 mmol/g, and then decreases rapidly over the range of qWc = 3.5 to 6.5 mmol/g to a lower limit where the rate is only 30% of the initial value.24 As a result, it is desirable to keep the adsorbed water concentration on the biocatalyst at or below 3 mmol/g. This water content will be referred to as the “deactivation limit”. Adsorption equilibrium isotherms are used to describe the partitioning of solutes for both the biocatalyst and the adsorbent resin. As shown by Migliorini et al.,24 only two of the components are significantly adsorbed:  propionic acid, which is adsorbed on the biocatalyst only, and water, which is adsorbed on both the biocatalyst and the adsorbent resin. In both cases, the adsorption isotherms are expressed as empirical functions of the thermodynamic activity in the reaction mixture, which were calculated using the UNIFAC model 42 with the parameter set of Hansen et al. 43 Inclusion of activity coefficients is necessary in this system because of the highly nonideal nature of the reaction mixture. The latter causes the thermodynamic activity and, hence, the adsorption isotherm, to vary dramatically as a function of conversion. As shown by Migliorini et al.,24 the water adsorption isotherms are S-shaped (type V) when plotted as a function of aW. For low aW values, water adsorption on the resin is about four times greater than on the biocatalyst. Adsorption of propionic acid on the biocatalyst follows a favorable type I isotherm, but the maximum amount adsorbed is low for our experimental conditions. All of the model parameters, with the exception of the axial dispersion coefficient, were determined by Migliorini et al.24 and are summarized in Table 3. The activity of the biocatalyst sample used in this work was lower than that used by Migliorini et al.;24 however, the concentration dependence and the effect of adsorbed water were the same. As a result, the only variation is the value of the rate coefficient .  Table 3.  Model Parametersaparametervalueunitsrm01.0 mmol/(h g) KDm6.5 × 10-5mol/L KAm3.0 × 10-2mol/L KDi5.0 mol/L KAi1.1 × 10-4mol/L K0.6 - kWc7.9 h-1kAc3.0 h-1kWa1.3 h-1The axial dispersion coefficient, DL, was determined as follows. First, breakthrough experiments using n-octane as a nonadsorbed tracer in hexane were  performed.23 A Peclet number Pe = udp/εbDL = 0.3 was found, in good agreement with the Peclet number predicted by the correlation of Chung and Wen. 44 Tracer experiments were then done using 3 mol/L diol in hexane. These experimental results are shown in Figure 3 along with model calculations. Although the diol is not adsorbed, the results of positive and negative concentration steps are quite different. In both cases, the stoichiometric centers of the curves occur at V/Vc ∼ 0.66, which coincides with the total void fraction of the column. However, while the positive concentration step yields a sharp curve, the negative concentration step yields a strongly tailing curve. This difference is attributable to viscous fingering. This is likely to occur when the more viscous diol solution (μ = 2.8 cp) is displaced by the less viscous hexane solvent (μ = 0.33 cp). In this case, the less viscous displacing fluid forms “fingers” that extend into the more viscous fluid at the rear boundary between the two fluids. These fingers become increasingly pronounced as the displacing fluid moves through the column, resulting in a long elution tail. Conversely, viscous fingering is not expected to affect the response to the positive concentration step because, in this case, the viscosity difference actually stabilizes the front. Lines show model predictions with different values of Pe = udp/εbDL.  High Resolution ImageDownload MS PowerPoint Slide Figure 4 Experimental and predicted profiles for run A (1-1-1 configuration):  (a) raffinate; (b) extract. Conditions are given in Table 1.  High Resolution ImageDownload MS PowerPoint SlideAs seen in Figure 3, while Pe = 0.3 provides a good prediction of the response to the positive concentration step, a much lower Pe value is needed to fit the response to the negative concentration step. It should be noted that in describing the SMBR system, axial dispersion and viscous fingering affect different components to a different extent. They have the greatest effect on the nonadsorbed species (the diol and the ester), while they are expected to have almost no effect on the adsorbed components (water and propionic acid), for which mass transfer resistances are dominant. Moreover, the effects of viscous fingering are expected to be different in the different zones of the SMBR system. Thus, to simplify the analysis, a single Pe value was used in the model simulations, chosen to provide the best fit of the SMBR data. A value of Pe = 0.06 was optimal and is intermediate between the two Pe values obtained in the diol tracer experiments. This value of Pe was used in all the simulations. More rigorous models incorporating an explicit description of viscous fingering could be developed. 45 However, it will be shown that the approximate modeling approach used in this work produces results in reasonable agreement with the experimental data without occurring in the detailed description of the fluid mechanics of viscous fingering which, as a minimum, would require a two-dimensional transient model. Results and DiscussionARTICLE SECTIONSJump ToExperimental results for SMBR run A are shown in Figure 4. The top figure shows the raffinate concentrations while the bottom figure shows those for the extract stream. This run corresponds to a 1−1−1 SMBR configuration with one bed in zone I, one bed in zone II, and one bed in zone III. Starting with initially clean beds, the concentrations build up in the system gradually during the first few cycles. As a result of the periodic switching of beds, a periodic steady-state is reached by  the fourth cycle. At this point the effluent concentrations become periodic functions of time with a period equal to the bed switching time. A better understanding of the interplay of the zones and of the periodic steady-state profiles can be obtained by plotting the raffinate concentrations as a function of the number of column volumes in zone III, V/Vc, rather than time. The results for the fifth period are shown in Figure 5 on an enlarged scale. At the start of the period, the bed that was just moved to zone III is filled with the 3 mol/L diol feed solution. Thus, initially, a high concentration of diol is seen in the raffinate. This diol is then rapidly displaced as this bed fills with the zone III feed. As this occurs the concentration of the ester formed in the reaction begins to rise. As shown by Migliorini et al.,24 the acid in zone III forms a reactive front whose speed depends on both the reaction rate and its adsorption isotherm. Downstream of this front no reaction takes place because the acid is absent. Thus, initially, only a portion of the reactor zone is active. As seen in Figure 5, the maximum ester concentration is attained approximately when the acid breaks through. When this occurs, acid and diol are simultaneously present throughout the length of the reactor zone and the maximum rate of ester production is obtained. It can be seen that the water concentration is kept very low in the raffinate. When the water begins to break through, the ester concentration begins to decline, indicating that equilibrium limitations have reduced the reaction rate. The extract profiles in Figure 4b demonstrate the regeneration of the adsorbent in zone I. During the first few cycles the beds contained little water so that the water concentration in the extract is low. By the third cycle, water produced by the reaction in zone III begins to appear in the extract, building up until the periodic steady state is reached. Conditions are given in Table 1.  High Resolution ImageDownload MS PowerPoint SlidePredicted effluent concentration profiles are shown in Figures 4 and 5. In general there is a good agreement between the model predictions and the experimental data for both the extract and raffinate. In fact, the agreement is quite impressive when one considers that  the thermodynamic activity coefficient of water varies over 2 orders of magnitude in the reactor zone for these experimental conditions. The initial acid breakthrough is not as well predicted. Most likely this is due to slight inaccuracies in the description of the highly favorable acid adsorption isotherm24 and by the fact that the LDF approximation is used to describe the rate of adsorption. The corresponding predicted axial profiles of adsorbed water on the biocatalyst and the adsorbent in zones I and III are shown in Figure 6 at the end of the period in the periodic steady state. The profiles in zone I show that both the Dowex resin and Lipozyme are sufficiently regenerated. The biocatalyst leaving zone I is in the fully active state (adsorbed water less than 3 mmol/g). Similarly, there is a very low concentration of water adsorbed on Lipozyme in zone III as most of the water formed in the reaction is adsorbed on the Dowex resin. Since the biocatalyst remains below 3 mmol/g of adsorbed water, full activity is maintained throughout the period. For these conditions, the conversion attained is limited by the rate of reaction and the reaction equilibrium, since the simultaneous removal of water keeps the biocatalyst away from the deactivation limit. The effect of adding a second bed to the reaction/adsorption zone (run B) is shown in Figure 7. The flow rates in this 1−1−2 SMBR configuration are the same as in run A. Thus the residence time in zone III is doubled. The extract and raffinate concentration profiles are qualitatively similar to the previous run. However, in this case a nearly complete conversion of the acid substrate occurs, and a much higher conversion of the diol leads to a higher purity ester product. Correspondingly, a higher concentration of water is seen in the extract (Figure 7b). Figure 8 shows the effect of adding a third bed to the reaction/adsorption zone. For simplicity, only the final five cycles are shown (from 12 to 27 h). For this 1−1−3 SMBR configuration (run C), the diol substrate concentration approaches small values in the raffinate stream toward the end of the period, resulting in an even higher ester purity. The corresponding predicted axial adsorbed water profiles in zone III are shown in Figure 9. It can be seen that although most of the water produced is adsorbed on the Dowex resin, the adsorbed water concentration on the biocatalyst has risen slightly above the 3 mmol/g deactivation limit in the first 40% of the first bed. This suggests that the switch time is near the maximum because any increase, corresponding to a decrease of the equivalent adsorbent velocity (see eq 1a), would cause further accumulation of water and a reduction in the catalytic activity. The acid feed rate is the same as run C. However, the diol feed rate and the extract flow rates are lower. Conversion of the acid is, however, now far from being complete, and a significant acid concentration breaks through. The adsorbed water profiles are shown in  Figure 11. In this case, the adsorbed water concentration has risen above the deactivation limit over the entire length of the first bed as well a portion of the second bed. The lower reaction rates caused by the accumulation of water, in turn, resulted in a lower conversion of the acid substrate. Since the diol feed rate was reduced for this run, a higher concentration of water is seen in the extract (Figure 10b). Experimental conditions of Figure 10.  High Resolution ImageDownload MS PowerPoint SlideFinally, the effect of adding an additional bed to the regeneration zone, zone I, is shown in Figure 12 (run E). The addition of another bed to the desorption section is expected to increase the desorption efficiency, allowing the diol feed flow rate to be lowered while maintaining a similar amount of regeneration. In this run, the diol feed flow rate was reduced from 0.77 to 0.40 cm3/min while keeping the switching time equal to 180 min and the acid feed flow rate equal to 0.11 cm3/min. The experimental and predicted raffinate profiles are quite similar to those obtained in the 1−1−2 configuration (see Figure 7). The extract water concentration profiles are quite different, however, as in this case a much smaller amount of diol feed is used as a desorbent. Because essentially the same amount of water is produced and recovered in the extract as in run C, the efficiency of using the desorbent has been increased substantially by the countercurrent operation with two beds in series in zone I. The axial profiles of adsorbed water corresponding to this run are shown in Figure 13 at the end of the period in the periodic steady state. As seen from these profiles, at the end of the period the first bed in zone I is regenerated sufficiently so that the water adsorbed on the biocatalyst is below the deactivation limit while more than half of the water adsorbed on the Dowex resin has been removed. Process Performance Parameters. In general, the optimization of the SMBR is dependent on the definition of an economic objective function. However, for simplicity, only the acid conversion and the ester purity in the raffinate stream were used in this work to compare different experimental conditions. A summary of the experimental and predicted values for these two quantities is given in Table 4 for periodic steady state conditions. The acid conversion is based on the period-average concentration in the raffinate, while the ester purity is calculated from the average raffinate concentrations excluding the bed void volume. These quantities can be compared directly with the corresponding equilibrium values for a nonseparating plug flow reactor,  which are calculated from the following relationships: where x* is the equilibrium conversion of the acid. For feed concentrations of the acid and diol substrates of 1 and 3 mol/L, we obtain x* = 67% and an ester purity of 17%. As seen in Table 4, the SMBR runs achieved both acid conversion and ester purity much higher than the corresponding equilibrium values. Increasing the number of beds in zone III from one to three (runs A−C) increases the acid conversion and the ester purity because of the longer residence time. Increasing the switching time from 180 to 240 min (runs C and D) increases the average ester purity in the raffinate because the diol concentration is reduced to a low value. Finally, including an additional bed in zone I (run E) yields a performance similar to that of run B, but with greatly reduced diol consumption. Performance Parameters % acid conversion% ester purity in raffinaterunexp.modelexp.model A 79 85 25 31 B 92 93 35 40 C 93 96 43 47 D 80 87 44 56 E 88 90 37 40a From ref 24.ConclusionsARTICLE SECTIONSJump ToIn this study, an enzymatic esterification has been coupled with the adsorption of water. Previously, this coupling has been shown to enhance the rate and ultimate conversion in batch reactors as well as the conversion during the transient operation of fixed-bed reactors.24 While these adsorptive reactors offered these advantages over conventional reactors, their operation was necessarily discontinuous. A continuous SMBR system, integrating reaction, adsorption of water, and regeneration, has been shown to be effective for this reaction. The process operates in a nearly continuous manner while overcoming equilibrium limitations and preventing deactivation of the biocatalyst by adsorbed water. The SMBR system offered two additional advantages:  reduced desorbent consumption due to maximizing the driving force for desorption through countercurrent operation, and internal recycle through zone II of a portion of the diol used as the regenerant. A mathematical model, based on independently determined descriptions of adsorption and reaction phenomena, was developed to predict the behavior of the SMBR system. In all cases, model predictions were in good agreement with the experimental results obtained in our laboratory scale system. Ester concentration profiles were predicted well, whereas the diol concentration profiles were predicted less accurately because of strong tailing behavior of this species. These predictions are impressive when one considers that they are dependent on the simultaneous description of a number of independent effects, including the calculation of activity coefficients that vary as much as 2 orders of magnitude over the conditions studied. The level of model accuracy attained was useful as a means of directing the experimental investigation and elucidating the performance-governing parameters. The model provides a useful tool  to investigate the effects of process variables and ultimately a powerful tool for process optimization. Protein and virus-like particle adsorption on perfusion chromatography media - ScienceDirect

ScienceDirectJournals & BooksHelpSearchInstitutionRegisterSign in PDFView PDFDownload Full IssueSearchJournal of Chromatography AVolume 1297, 5 July 2013, Pages 96-105Protein and virus-like particle adsorption on perfusion chromatography mediaAuthor links open overlay panelYigeWuaJaredSimonsbSarahHoosonbDickyAbrahambGiorgioCartaaPersonEnvelopeShow moreNavigate DownPlusAdd to MendeleyShareShareCited ByCitehttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.chroma.2013.04.062Get rights and contentHighlights•Architecture and pore size distribution of POROS HS 50 are determined.•Perfusion effects on the adsorption of biomolecules are visualized.•Perfusion is negligible for proteins up to 150 kDa.•Perfusion becomes significant for a 700 kDa protein at 1000 cm/h.•100 nm VLPs are largely excluded and bind only at the particle surface.AbstractThe structural and protein adsorption characteristics of the perfusion chromatography matrix POROS® HS 50 are determined. Transmission electron microscopy shows a broad distribution of pore sizes with 100–500 nm through-pores transecting a network of much smaller pores formed by aggregates of microgranules about 100 nm in size. Dextran standards, proteins, and virus-like particles (VLPs) show size-exclusion behavior consistent with such a bimodal distribution of pore sizes. For non-binding conditions, the trends in height equivalent to a theoretical plate (HETP) as a function of mobile phase velocity and molecular size are consistent with perfusion suggesting that a fraction of the mobile phase between 0.0005 and 0.0008 flows through the particles. This small fraction provides little or no enhancement of intraparticle mass transfer for relatively small proteins (lysozyme and IgG) even at 1000 cm/h, but can contribute substantially to transport for large proteins (thyroglobulin) and VLPs. Intraparticle concentration profiles during transient adsorption are determined by confocal microscopy in batch and flow systems. The profiles are spherically symmetrical indicating a dominance of diffusion for smaller proteins in both batch and flow systems but become highly asymmetrical and skewed in the direction of flow for thyroglobulin at 1000 cm/h. Estimates of the convective enhancement of intraparticle transport for these conditions based on the confocal measurements are consistent with estimates of the intraparticle Peclet number and previously published models. Adsorption of VLPs, however, was found to be confined to a thin layer on the outer surface of the particles indicting that bound VLPs block access to the underlying pore network and suggesting that pores larger than those present on the resin studies are needed to take advantage of the effects of perfusion for the adsorption of large VLPs.Navigate LeftPrevious article in issueNext article in issueNavigate RightKeywordsPerfusion chromatographyMass transferProteinsVirus-like-particlesRecommended articlesCited by (0)View AbstractCopyright © 2013 Elsevier B.V.
